revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-18 12:30:41.000000000', 'message': 'Fix backup compression unit tests

Cinder backup tests for compression were incorrectly testing the size of
the compression data, instead of testing against the compressed data
they were checking the tuple (algorithm, compressed_data).

This patches fixes those tests.

Change-Id: I02f79a1ccc1af29e1f843e94c0618c8e4962bdae
(cherry picked from commit fd671c77cd93e8a5a5bafbee7f24564fb780a044)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix backup compression unit tests

Cinder backup tests for compression were incorrectly testing the size of
the compression data, instead of testing against the compressed data
they were checking the tuple (algorithm, compressed_data).

This patches fixes those tests.

Change-Id: I02f79a1ccc1af29e1f843e94c0618c8e4962bdae
(cherry picked from commit fd671c77cd93e8a5a5bafbee7f24564fb780a044)

[{'created': '2017-10-05 14:55:48.000000000', 'message': "VMAX driver - detach volume shouldn't remove from volume groups

Detaching a volume in VMAX removes the volume from all its current
storage groups and returns it to its default storage group. This is not
desired behaviour when the volume is a member of a generic volume group.
The volume should only be removed from the storage group associated
with the masking view related to the detach operation (or all masking
views in the case of a force detach). This patch rectifies the issue.

Change-Id: I065ffba9615af54998ae94a8d2d2fd3853f462cb
Closes-Bug: 1721207

commit_message:
VMAX driver - detach volume shouldn't remove from volume groups

Detaching a volume in VMAX removes the volume from all its current
storage groups and returns it to its default storage group. This is not
desired behaviour when the volume is a member of a generic volume group.
The volume should only be removed from the storage group associated
with the masking view related to the detach operation (or all masking
views in the case of a force detach). This patch rectifies the issue.

Change-Id: I065ffba9615af54998ae94a8d2d2fd3853f462cb
Closes-Bug: 1721207

subject: VMAX driver - concurrently deleting volumes can fail

commit_message:
VMAX driver - concurrently deleting volumes can fail

When concurrently deleting volumes, sometimes the task fails leaving
the volume in an 'error_deleting' state. This only occurs when
image_volume_cache_enabled is True because a temp snapvx session is
created. This same issue also occurs when there is a batch delete
of snapshots from the same source volume. The fix locks the delete
snapvx session using the source DeviceID as key.

Change-Id: I1f72a8567faa78fec447b9e0a6f948514b43a864
Closes-Bug: #1714922

CI is happy now.'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2017-08-30 13:25:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

So this patch looks like it spawns a thread to monitor the copy going on the backend.   What does the driver report up to the volume manager before this process is complete?   Is the volume marked as created in the cinder DB?   What happens to that status if the background clone fails?   What happens when someone wants to snapshot/attach/clone/delete the clone during the background process if the volume is marked as available in the cinder db?'}, {'account_id': 17564, 'date': '2017-08-31 06:24:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Hi Walter, driver reports up to the volume manager that this volume is available before this process is complete. because for DS8K storage, it can be used(attached and written/read) although copy process is still ongoing. This reduces tons of time in the scenario that user want to deploy and use a lot of instances quickly when these instances are booted from DS8K, especially when the bootable source volume is so large and they need to prepare a lot of target volumes before booting instances.

If copy process failed at the end, the relevant instances will have problem and when user check the status of volume, they can know what happen from the metadata of volume because this patch updates the metadata of the volume when copy finished.

Regarding take snapshot or clone the target volume, they will be failed(driver has checked it and will throw exception). but we will tell user that this feature is only for booting large instances in the documentation, and when they enable the option in the metadata to use this feature, we will make sure they totally understand what does this option mean.'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2017-09-05 11:57:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Hi jiamin.  What happens when a user deletes the volume that's being cloned?   I just removed the 3PAR capability to do a background copy, because it basically results in a volume that you can't do much with until the background process is completed.   

Have you tried running Rally tests against this?   In my process of trying to enable active/active clustering support for the driver, running parallel rally tests against the driver with clone caused lots of problems."}, {'account_id': 17564, 'date': '2017-09-06 06:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Hi Walter, I am sorry that I forgot to answer the question about delete.

if user delete the volume which is being cloned, DS8K will throw exception showing that this volume is in a Copy Services relationship, and it still copies data from source volume until copy finished.

Unfortunately cinder will mark the status of this volume as error although it can be used, and user need to reset its status to previous one after delete.

In this patch, during copy, I added an information to show that the flashcopy is starting in the volume metadata in order to remind user that it is being cloned. but I believe that it still can not make sure all of users can notify it when they want to clone/delete this volume, because it is not obvious as the status field of volume.

About active/active clustering support, this is really a big question, first of all, I afraid DS8K driver is really hard/impossible to support A/A, this is caused by the design of DS8K, especially CG. 

so I only passed self.host from manage.py to XIV/DS8K driver instead of both self.cluster and self.host at the same time.

I really hope there is a perfect solution for DS8K driver, but match it with base cinder still have a long way to go.
 
Thank you.'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2017-09-06 13:52:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: -Code-Review

Hi Jiamin,
  So that's pretty similar to the problem that I ran into with doing this same type of thing with the 3PAR driver.   I was able to catch that exception at delete time, then go to the 3PAR and cancel the background copy and then try and clean up.   I ended up with some house cleaning that was nearly impossible to fix after canceling, which would then cause other problems later on.   So I just decided to punt on the background copy capability here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/499806/

I would suggest trying out the rally tests here :
https://github.com/hemna/rally-plugins/blob/master/tasks/create-from-volume-and-delete-volume.json

I ramped up the parallelism on that and ran into lots of problems with clone and delete operations with rally and the background copy.
If you want to eventually enable your driver to work in a clustered active/active HA ability, you will need to get that to work.

I'll remove my -1, but I just wanted you to be aware that this type of thing can lead to other nasty problems that aren't obvious unless you test more than just what tempest provides."}, {'account_id': 17564, 'date': '2017-09-07 02:22:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Hi Walter,

Thank you very much for your reminder, all of your questions are really good points and I think I need to reconsider this feature in case user misunderstand the option to enable this feature and complain why some operations(snapshot/delete) failed afterwards.

Considering you have a lot of experience on this issue and deep knowledge on cinder, can you help me to estimate how hard it is to implement a mechanism in base cinder to support asynchronously clone? Unfortunately, I think this question is not only related to cinder, but also nova, because nova may use the volume that is being cloned, and it needs to handle the case that clone failed at the end.

if there is a lot of work to do, do you think the current solution
can be used as a temporary one? and driver endures all of its shortages at this moment.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-10-10 00:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

commit_message:
DS8K: support clone volume asynchronously

when cloning volume in DS8K, driver doesn't need to wait until
flashcopy finished in some cases, so this patch provides an option
in volume metadata that can be used to tell driver to wait for
flashcopy completed or not.

Implements: blueprint ds8k-async-clone
Change-Id: I51829e7667d3ac148978e1799cecfea1920f838f

I think this option doesn't really make sense under the backend_defaults section. It's not a default that applies to multiple backends, so that's a little confusing there.

I think it should either be updated to be back under defaults, or probably what would make more sense is to move it under the zone_manager section since that is all it applies to.

Whichever one we do, the docs would also need to be updated:

[{'created': '2017-10-16 08:07:46.000000000', 'message': "Fetch 'zoning_mode' from 'backend_defaults' section

Cinder registers 'zoning_mode' into 'backend_defaults' config
section since patch: [1]. Update the methods which still
try to fetch the value from default section.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/453654/

Change-Id: I5b31082296f5bff5089d0f42a62d44bb009d177d
"}, {'created': '2017-10-17 02:44:23.000000000', 'message': "Move 'zoning_mode' back to DEFAULT section

We moved 'zoning_mode' option to 'backend_defaults'
section since patch: [1]. But it has two issues:

1. It can not work because we still fetch the value
from the default section [2].
2. From the view of our current desgin. It's only
used in our framework code, which means it still can
not work if we overwrite the default value in one
specific backend section, such as:

[backend_defaults]
zoning_mode=fabric
[lvmbackend_1]
zoning_mode=other_value

Move this option back to DEFAULT section until we
need to.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/453654/
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/zonemanager/utils.py#L56

Change-Id: I5b31082296f5bff5089d0f42a62d44bb009d177d

commit_message:
Move 'zoning_mode' back to DEFAULT section

We moved 'zoning_mode' option to 'backend_defaults'
section since patch: [1]. But it has two issues:

1. It can not work because we still fetch the value
from the default section [2].
2. From the view of our current design. It's only
used in our framework code, which means it still can
not work if we overwrite the default value in one
specific backend section, such as:

[backend_defaults]
zoning_mode=fabric
[lvmbackend_1]
zoning_mode=other_value

Move this option back to DEFAULT section until we
need to.

Closes-Bug: #1724418

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/453654/
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/zonemanager/utils.py#L56

Change-Id: I5b31082296f5bff5089d0f42a62d44bb009d177d

commit_message:
Dell EMC PS: Optimize parsing of capacity info from backend

The backend api returns large amounts of information and
times out when there are lots of volumes. Accelerated the
process by terminating the parsing after the capacity info
is retrieved.

Closes Bug: #1661154

Change-Id: I1f0adaa8e25cd3ec74084b22bbe1573b92713959
(cherry picked from commit a9a0c2ee2e973d0594f2707d64846e882e179c94)

commit_message:
Add display_name to solidfire volume attributes

This just adds another mapping to the SolidFire volume
attributes during create.  We add a `cinder-name` key
to the internal SolidFire volume attributes which has a
value set to the cinder display_name attribute of the volume.

In the case of a volume with no display_name we set the
attribute value to an empty string.

Change-Id: Idbfbf8be7ef34c134c7723891aba8b3baa2ab43a

commit_message:
Add v3 api-ref for updating specific extra specs for a volume type

This patch adds v3 api-ref for the following volume type API:
Update specific extra specs assigned to a volume type.

Change-Id: Ib8622870d53cbdc249aa465ce62ed45dea2b4089

commit_message:
Replace http with https for doc links in cinder

1) Update doc links according to OpenStack document migration
2) Use https instead of http for docs links
For example:
(1)http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide/blockstorage_nfs_backend.html
->https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/admin/blockstorage-nfs-backend.html
(2)http://docs.openstack.org/oslo.i18n/latest/user/index.html
->https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.i18n/latest/user/index.html
(3)http://docs.openstack.org/ --> https://docs.openstack.org/
(4)http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide/blockstorage_multi_backend.html
->https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/admin/blockstorage-multi-backend.html

Change-Id: I7fcdc4453cb3bad713c7d770012411701cca742b
Closes-Bug:#1710054

commit_message:
DS8000 ConsistencyGroup failed to update group with volumes

While adding a volume to ConsistencyGroup the failed with TypeError: sequence
item 0: expected string, tuple found.  This could have happened if the driver
did not find the specified LSS pairs matching that of the available volume
pools.  The driver intended to throw an error message with available_lss_pairs
but failed to concatinate the data to the error message with TypeError
exception.

The proposed fix attempts to address this issue by simplifying the
concat of available_lss_pairs as string and then adding to error message.

Closes-bug: #1722769

Change-Id: I4c154b15991fd624d91bd3e3472d25c714fb8525

subject: ScaleIO Driver: Backup volume via snapshot

commit_message:
ScaleIO Driver: Backup volume via snapshot

When a volume is in-use, the ScaleIO driver can achieve the backup of
that volume through creating a temp snapshot, and then backing-up the
snapshot.

Change-Id: I6330cb1b6644de5f470b198f035933ff676c1bce

subject: Fix backup compression unit tests

commit_message:
Fix backup compression unit tests

Cinder backup tests for compression were incorrectly testing the size of
the compression data, instead of testing against the compressed data
they were checking the tuple (algorithm, compressed_data).

This patches fixes those tests.

Change-Id: I02f79a1ccc1af29e1f843e94c0618c8e4962bdae

commit_message:
Api-ref: Add missing api response for volume transfer

The volume transfer accept and create API missed the api response,
this change is to add them for both V2 and V3.

Closes-bug: #1723867
Change-Id: I4f8005633ed1eb53ab08b3493cdc97d44103dafa

commit_message:
Add v3 api-ref for showing all/specific extra specs for a volume type

This patch adds v3 api-ref for two APIs:
1. Show all extra specs assigned to a volume type
2. Show specific extra specs assigned to a volume type

Change-Id: Id5771ee7e52748374ae6a3167116589273000297

commit_message:
Kaminario K2: Add non discovery iSCSI multipath

Current Kaminario K2 driver only supports iSCSI multipathing using
discovery (sendtargets), which in some cases may be undesirable, since a
broken primary path could prevent an attachment.

This code adds the possibility of not using discovery mode and return
all connection information when `initialize_connection` is called, which
should provide increased reliability.

Change-Id: I7932b1d952844b49cfdb504ed0ba188b489d7f44

[{'account_id': 27059, 'date': '2017-10-11 22:10:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2017-10-11 22:10:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2017-10-11 22:21:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
FlashSystems: permit snapshot/clone volumes larger than source

Permit clone volumes and volumes created from snapshots to
be larger than their source volumes; implemented in response
to failures in the following CI tests:
  * VolumesSnapshotTestJSON.test_volume_from_snapshot
  * VolumesCloneTest.test_create_from_volume

Change-Id: I21511e5c4db62563c61815c1671e8bb44ad3f427
Closes-Bug: #1560655

commit_message:
Deprecate SolidFire Image Caching feature

We've had a general solution to image-caching in
Cinder for a while now and it works well, so we
can remove the SolidFire specific implementation
in favor of using the general solution.

https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/\
admin/blockstorage-image-volume-cache.html

This patch marks the SolidFire config option
as deprecated, and we'll remove the feature
altogether in the next release.

Change-Id: Iefc207955e4718a7d9c3b235b133a4c629977d03

commit_message:
[policy in code] Add support for service, limits

This patch adds policy in code support for capabilities,
hosts, services, limits and depends on the quota patch [1].

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508091/

Change-Id: Ib2bac2d28d950c0d8b734a54e300dd4185d98ca9
Partial-Implements: blueprint policy-in-code

commit_message:
Vzstorage: improvement of create_cloned_volume

Prior to this patch Vzstorage driver left "tmp-snap-*.qemu_img_info"
cache files, as _delete_snapshot from remotefs doesn't delete
*.qemu_img_info files. If we rename create_snapshot in Vzstorage
to _create_snapshot we 1) solve above problem
2) don't have to use locking decorator

We also rename _create_cloned_volume so as it complies with its
specific usage only for ploop volumes

Change-Id: I5215c58966713cac0242c1cdb6cb1df9c3a710b3

commit_message:
[policy in code] Add support for group, g-snapshot resources

This patch adds policy in code support for group&group
snapshot resources and depends on the backup patch [1].

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/507015/

Change-Id: If95a8aaa70614902a06420d1afa487827f8a3f03
Partial-Implements: blueprint policy-in-code

commit_message:
Add documentation for API 'validate_setup_for_nested_quota_use'

Documentation for API 'validate_setup_for_nested_quota_use' is
missing. Fix it.

Change-Id: Ica3d468856bad045c2bdd30a0f86924cc0aeb572

commit_message:
VMAX driver - documentation updates around versions

Correct the minimum versions for Solutions Enabler and Unisphere.
Add QoS to the list of supported operations.

Change-Id: Ief648a8a464d1bd6f463774d48438441ae9502e2
Closes-Bug: #1722497

[{'created': '2017-10-10 10:42:17.000000000', 'message': 'VMAX driver - remove WLP stats

Workload Planner(WLP) headroom calculations are not always accurate
for All Flash arrays. Because WLP is generally always enabled on
Unisphere, it is best use SRP calculations instead.

Change-Id: Id5e59fce2ea5958bfcd4fbadb609f8f6cad42aa8
Closes-Bug: #1714503
(cherry picked from commit 635e892cc8e7541e83697792c9f45d056460c845)

commit_message:
VMAX driver - remove WLP stats

Workload Planner(WLP) headroom calculations are not always accurate
for All Flash arrays. Because WLP is generally always enabled on
Unisphere, it is best use SRP calculations instead.

Change-Id: Id5e59fce2ea5958bfcd4fbadb609f8f6cad42aa8
Closes-Bug: #1714503
(cherry picked from commit 635e892cc8e7541e83697792c9f45d056460c845)

subject: Remove deprecated VD base classes which are not used now

commit_message:
Add multipath enhancement to Storwize iSCSI driver

Add multipath enhancement to Storwize iSCSI driver.
target portals, iqns and luns will be returned in
initialize_connection if multipath is being used.

Change-Id: Ie9bcb94f95effee7f6407aabe268cc0637a602f3
Implements: blueprint storwize-iscsi-multipath-enhancement
(cherry picked from commit ad59cb5ac2fdc93cdcc93ac582c948a2a820a124)

subject: NEC driver: Fix exception in terminate_connection with no connector

commit_message:
NEC driver: Fix exception in terminate_connection with no connector

NEC driver required the connector object not be None.
This patch allows for the connector to be None by force detach.

Change-Id: Ib83edf85d086305341f94f6810fcdecb21fc7937
Closes-Bug: #1721461

commit_message:
Add v3 api-ref for deleting extra spec for a volume type

This patch adds v3 api-ref for the API: delete a specific extra spec
for a volume type.

Change-Id: I9b0c1527247aaebe7dc1acc71a376cb41108ee69

commit_message:
Replace the usage of some aliases in tempest

In tempest, following aliases have been moved in version Pike
and will be removed in version Queens:ad
* manager > os_primary [1]
* admin_manager > os_admin [2]
* os_adm > os_admin [3]
* os > os_primary [4]
* alt_manager > os_alt [5]

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/468036/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/467852/
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/467605/
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/466991/
[5] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/457555/

Change-Id: Ie3b93dd2cf457a5cb42a53eadc9f9fd5cec1f118

commit_message:
ScaleIO Driver - adding cache and refactoring tests

Changing static lists to a simple cache.
Refactoring some of the unit tests to simplify maintenance.

Related-Bug: #1699573

Change-Id: Idff127801da9e286a6b634594e5577eeb9782571

commit_message:
Add .stestr.conf configuration

os-testr has moved over to use stestr instead of testr. While this
is usually compaible with existing settings, there is a warning
that is emitted when .stestr.conf is not present. It is usually
able to fall back to parsing the .testr.conf file, but to be more
correct and to prevent future problems we should update the config.

Change-Id: I11e43cff87cad20b9c880e276e20a04123f830fb

commit_message:
Remove newton-compat upgrade code on service startup

This upgrade compat check code was marked for removal
in Ocata. Since we're now in Queens, and this is burning
time on every service start, let's remove it.

Change-Id: I8528752630276bd6e2348f27721238115de504cd
Related-Bug: #1722326

commit_message:
Remove Tegile volume driver

This driver was marked as deprecated and unsupported in Pike due to lack
of CI. This has not change and it will now be removed.

Change-Id: I1920f905fdf83b01840e86646dc948fd3a113536

subject: Remove ZTE volume driver

commit_message:
Remove ZTE volume driver

This driver was marked as deprecated and unsupported in Pike due to lack
of CI. This has not changed and it is now being removed.

Change-Id: I39a450159becb4d32b63e6073c3fcd6f08bd93a3

subject: Remove X-IO volume driver

commit_message:
Remove X-IO volume driver

This driver was marked deprecated and unsupported in Pike due to lack of
CI. This has not changed and it is now removed.

Change-Id: I475172f16784ab9cab2194589851ec7ce01d46a7

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-09-06 15:57:58.000000000', 'message': "RBD: Fix stats reporting

Current RBD code is incorrectly reporting the stats of the pool in the
following ways:

- `provisioned_capacity_gb` contains physical space used by cinder created
  volumes.
- `free_capacity_gb` is not taking into account that pools can have quota
  restrictions and they should be used as the reference for the free capacity.
- `total_capacity` dynamically changes, which means that there is no way to
  have a fixed over provisioning capacity.

This patch fixes the stats reporting making sure we return the right
values in `provisioned_capacity_gb` and `free_capacity_gb`, and allows
us to use a static calculation of the `total_capacity` using
`report_dynamic_total_capacity` configuration option.

We don't report `allocated_capacity_gb` because this is something that
is calculated by the Cinder core code and should not be reported by
drivers, even if it's not currently working as expected [1][2].

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1712549
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1706057

Change-Id: I1e82bf9d0b6cc0fb1d1fc2dd8b8ccc59aea3f73f
Closes-Bug: #1706060
(cherry picked from commit 8469109016bcfd5806e230202e1996a8ba649535)
Conflicts:
	cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_rbd.py
	cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py
(cherry picked from commit 7f70f99a9b008f9ceef36e5ee3d1ed10c7053a37)

	cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_rbd.py
	cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py

commit_message:
RBD: Fix stats reporting

Current RBD code is incorrectly reporting the stats of the pool in the
following ways:

- `provisioned_capacity_gb` contains physical space used by cinder created
  volumes.
- `free_capacity_gb` is not taking into account that pools can have quota
  restrictions and they should be used as the reference for the free capacity.
- `total_capacity` dynamically changes, which means that there is no way to
  have a fixed over provisioning capacity.

This patch fixes the stats reporting making sure we return the right
values in `provisioned_capacity_gb` and `free_capacity_gb`, and allows
us to use a static calculation of the `total_capacity` using
`report_dynamic_total_capacity` configuration option.

We don't report `allocated_capacity_gb` because this is something that
is calculated by the Cinder core code and should not be reported by
drivers, even if it's not currently working as expected [1][2].

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1712549
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1706057

Change-Id: I1e82bf9d0b6cc0fb1d1fc2dd8b8ccc59aea3f73f
Closes-Bug: #1706060
(cherry picked from commit 8469109016bcfd5806e230202e1996a8ba649535)
Conflicts:
	cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_rbd.py
	cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py
(cherry picked from commit 8d7f37e810d3228d8b79e4add1a383abe516d9bb)
Conflicts:
      cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_rbd.py
      cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py

commit_message:
Remove Reduxio volume driver

This driver was marked as deprecated and unsupported in Pike due to
lack of CI. This has not changed and it is now being removed.

Change-Id: I463a490637e31745bd92bb048bc798a66bd260c7

subject: Remove QNAP volume driver

commit_message:
Remove QNAP volume driver

The QNAP driver was marked as deprecated and unsupported in Pike due
to not meeting CI requirements. This situation has not changed and
it will now be removed.

Change-Id: I29a874ebe0ebaeca58b428faa0bab50482baf6f1

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-05 02:07:41.000000000', 'message': 'NetApp ONTAP: Fix reporting of provisioned_capacity_gb

The ONTAP drivers in Cinder ("7mode" and "cmode") cannot
reliably and efficiently track provisioned_capacity_gb as expected
by the Cinder scheduler.

The driver authors originally assumed that provisioned_capacity_gb
is consumed space on the backend. This results in miscalculation of
over subscription in the Cinder scheduler.

The fix adopted here is to remove this wrong reporting and rely on
calculation of the provisioned_capacity_gb in the scheduler.

Change-Id: Ic106dbcae8ceaac265b710756ab1874e445ca826
Closes-Bug: #1714209
(cherry picked from commit 42b8b7fe60ffdd7a7772dc0ab228265dc83344bc)
'}]
commit_message:
NetApp ONTAP: Fix reporting of provisioned_capacity_gb

The ONTAP drivers in Cinder ("7mode" and "cmode") cannot
reliably and efficiently track provisioned_capacity_gb as expected
by the Cinder scheduler.

The driver authors originally assumed that provisioned_capacity_gb
is consumed space on the backend. This results in miscalculation of
over subscription in the Cinder scheduler.

The fix adopted here is to remove this wrong reporting and rely on
calculation of the provisioned_capacity_gb in the scheduler.

Change-Id: Ic106dbcae8ceaac265b710756ab1874e445ca826
Closes-Bug: #1714209
(cherry picked from commit 42b8b7fe60ffdd7a7772dc0ab228265dc83344bc)

commit_message:
Brocade: Add HTTP connection cleanup

Method for get device mapping opens
connection to the switch but does not
close the connection.  Add finally
block to close the session.

Closes Bug: #1718762

commit_message:
Brocade: Add HTTP connection cleanup

Method for get device mapping opens
connection to the switch but does not
close the connection.  Add finally
block to close the session.

Closes Bug: #1718762

Change-Id: Ic4c7fd66858039db3f9d09a0babd5601b25a95e3

commit_message:
Remove Infortrend drivers

The Infortrend drivers were marked as deprecated and unsupported in Pike
due to lack of CI. This situation has not changed and they will now be
removed.

Change-Id: I0f1d12776cfa553b117c5b3698b2ae0c9c88735e

[{'created': '2017-10-03 19:41:57.000000000', 'message': 'Remove deprecated heartbeat options

Cluster locking heartbeat options were marked deprecated in
42dafd2705a8cb4346c396376977c705e55d9e7c with the move to using
the tooz built in hearbeating. These options are now removed.

Note, in the release note for the deprecation we actually stated
these options were removed, not deprecated, so this patch does
not include an additional release note pointing this out.

Change-Id: Iae30e9263044a7ef04fbe5b826cfcc7aa41add5a
'}]
commit_message:
Remove deprecated heartbeat options

Cluster locking heartbeat options were marked deprecated in
42dafd2705a8cb4346c396376977c705e55d9e7c with the move to using
the tooz built in hearbeating. These options are now removed.

Note, in the release note for the deprecation we actually stated
these options were removed, not deprecated, so this patch does
not include an additional release note pointing this out.

Change-Id: Iae30e9263044a7ef04fbe5b826cfcc7aa41add5a

commit_message:
Remove deprecated osapi_volume_base_URL

This config option was basically the same as public_endpoint and was
deprecated in Pike in favor of using that option instead. This now
removes it completely.

Change-Id: I405a404add187ba62357e541dfa1e8b39703ba18

commit_message:
Dell EMC PS: Optimize parsing of capacity info from backend

The backend api returns large amounts of information and
times out when there are lots of volumes. Accelerated the
process by terminating the parsing after the capacity info
is retrieved.

Closes Bug: #1661154

Change-Id: I1f0adaa8e25cd3ec74084b22bbe1573b92713959

commit_message:
Dell EMC PS: Fix over-subscription ratio stats

Fixed the provisioned_capacity_gb to use the VolumeReportedSpace
to calculate the over-subscription ratio stats in the Dell EMC
PS volume driver.

Closes Bug: #1719659

Change-Id: I2caa5f2763ec343b0bc875e707924ff9b6424ce5

commit_message:
Doc: Move generalized_filters to admin

This is not a man page, so move it to the admin dir
instead of "man".

Change-Id: I6d128a5bc30b8d9ac1a0b7a200088b39a1777b05

commit_message:
Add ploop to parallels naming conversion

It worked silently until src_format was started
to be passed to convert_image in
I4071927c491870626fe174b75ecaf8ef6da39cf5

Now we should also have ploop-to-parallels mapping
as in upload_volume.
Also, place all conversions to a single structure.

Change-Id: I8ad66a625f12cc48e1daec51e9f8abe6ae8932d6

Do we need/want to do the same thing to the cluster.id?

How does this work for something like rolling upgrades? @patrick

>Do we need/want to do the same thing to the cluster.id?
Currently cluster.id is Null unless/untll you have a cluster, otherwise I could exploit that for the shared_targets handle :)

> How does this work for something like rolling upgrades? 
Quite well, thanks for asking

> I suspect this is maybe just me not being super familiar with the process, but it >seems like swapping id's 

There's no swap in this case so you're good; the column doesn't exist so introducing it doesn't have an expectation that we have to worry about.  If you're using the UUID column you already have the upgrade, otherwise, it never existed so you are not using it anyway.  See what I mean there?

To be clear, what I mean is I'm not changing anything in terms of what's in use as far as the old service ID, that's the same doesn't change here at all.

> when upgrading the DB would require us to never keep the id's in memory without > the ability to find them again some other way... is that the case?

If we wanted to actually change the service.id to a UUID that would be true, and that's fairly easy to do; that's what we did when we changed targets; sort of like you described we introduced a "legacy_mapping" column temporarily.  Anyway, doesn't matter because we're not swapping here, just adding a new *thing*'}, {'account_id': 24502, 'date': '2017-09-28 19:38:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build succeeded.

- dsvm-veritas-hyperscale-cinder-driver http://52.35.51.88/09/508209/2/check/dsvm-veritas-hyperscale-cinder-driver/f162104 : SUCCESS in 1h 51m 15s'}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2017-09-28 19:54:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ohhh duh, I see now. Should have finished my coffee before reviewing :) In my mind we were making the id the uuid, but yea, no problemo here.

And yea, for the scenario like shared targets using the cluster id is what I was thinking. The first cut of the shared targets using the host name worked because it was the same for each service in the cluster, but this would lead us towards unique id's for each node in the cluster. Seems like the logic to use it would be pretty simple, just check if the service has a cluster and use that instead of the service id, same as we do for the name/topic I think."}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2017-09-28 20:01:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2017-09-28 20:20:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Add uuid to services entries

Our services ID column is still just an integer and that's *ok* for the
most part.  There are things that it would be nice to advertise a
more meaningful and unique identifier to the users of services though.

This change adds an indexable UUID column to the services, this will
be useful for things like identifying backends without leaking
details to end users.

commit_message:
Fix Tempest Volume Revert test

When we stopped using magic strings for the microversions in Cinder on
change Ib3a80fee6caaabb49af097aa197f550c65d94985 we broke the Volume
Revert Tempest test because we started sending requests to do the revert
with API microversion 3.0 and the minimum version is 3.40.

This patch fixes it.

Closes-bug: 1720855
Change-Id: Ib85411c7f6f5cc9ad33e41f1aba18021703e4913

subject: [Fullstack] Limit number of test workers to 4
messages: [{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-02-23 09:58:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-02-23 12:41:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-02-23 17:54:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2018-02-25 11:28:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-23 09:58:43.000000000', 'message': 'DNM Test how fullstack will work with 4 test workers

Change-Id: I58cb2ade598e8dc2377e6187483cb39881a9dc3c
'}, {'created': '2018-02-23 12:41:26.000000000', 'message': '[Fullstack] Limit number of test workers to 4

By default there is as many test workers running fullstack
tests as cores on host.
On gate tests it is 8 cores so 8 test workers.
Each such workers spawns own neutron-server and agents.
That cause quite big load on such test node. From my tests
it looks that it can be up to 25.
By lowering number of test workers to 4 I observed that
load is at max about 10.
Overall time of tests is longer for about 10-15 minutes
(about 45-50 minutes with 8 workers and about 60-65 minutes
with 4 workers).

Change-Id: I58cb2ade598e8dc2377e6187483cb39881a9dc3c
'}]
commit_message:
[Fullstack] Limit number of test workers to 4

By default there is as many test workers running fullstack
tests as cores on host.
On gate tests it is 8 cores so 8 test workers.
Each such workers spawns own neutron-server and agents.
That cause quite big load on such test node. From my tests
it looks that it can be up to 25.
By lowering number of test workers to 4 I observed that
load is at max about 10.
Overall time of tests is longer for about 10-15 minutes
(about 45-50 minutes with 8 workers and about 60-65 minutes
with 4 workers).

Change-Id: I58cb2ade598e8dc2377e6187483cb39881a9dc3c

commit_message:
use DVR constants from neutron-lib

The L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR_NO_EXTERNAL and DVR_SNAT_BOUND constants were
rehomed into neutron-lib with Ieb9374f5483a0ab2306592ab901686ca374db1c8
This patch consumes them by removing them from neutron and using the
constants from neutron-lib instead.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: Ib63a523721a2fa3d1a978a729de28e6a2e560ef6

commit_message:
[doc] Support networking guide for VPNaaS

Current networking docs is lacking VPNaaS.
This patch addresses the gap and improves docs as
discussed in Boston summit.

Closes-bug: 1692131
Change-Id: Id59795ea25a4af171a254fc0da55bb767580eb5d

commit_message:
Schedule request to scheduler when manage existing snapshot

Pass the request to scheduler service rather than volume
service in order to check backend's capacity.

Partial-Implements: bp inspection-mechanism-for-capacity-limited-host
Change-Id: Iafaa48b908c26c1fa6862a8dfc27b43d525847e4

commit_message:
Fix AZ not matching backend after migration

When we migrate, or retype with migration, a volume between availability
zones we are setting the AZ of the migrated volume to the same AZ as the
source volume, so we end up with a volume where the AZ does not match
the backend's AZ.

This patch fixes this issue for the generic migration code as well as
the optimized driver migration.

Change-Id: Ia1bf3ae0b7cd6d209354024848aef6029179d8e4
Closes-Bug: #1747949

* Lenovo-iSCSI http://os-logs.tristero.net/lenovo-ci/17/546717/3/Lenovo-iSCSI : FAILURE in 0:05.03'}, {'account_id': 10058, 'date': '2018-02-22 11:42:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

There's also another thing we need to think and we could change in this patch. publish_service_capabilities is being called at will in some functions (init_host, delete_volume, retype, delete_group). This does not seem to be correct. It should either: 1 - be called only on init_host and them once every 60s, or, 2 - be called on init_host and in all operations that add, remove[1] or extend volumes.
On option 1, we guarantee that operations will not be delayed by the driver get_stats function that can, in some drivers take a considerable amount of time. 
For option 2, he would have a tight coupling between data in schedulers and volume service, but we fall in the delay problem.
Is there a way to kick the periodic task in a way it is run before the timer expires? So we could go for option 2 without the delaying.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29599/"}, {'account_id': 24814, 'date': '2018-02-22 11:52:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-21 18:02:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix reporting old stats

For the stats reporting we have a decoupled implementation where the
gathering of stats from the backend and the submission of these stats to
the schedulers are run in independent periodic tasts.

The problem with this implementation is that we'll be getting old stats
all the time because of the threading model we are using.

Since we have greenthreads we will not switch threads until we do I/O,
so if the _publish_service_capabilities periodic task is invoked first
we won't switch to the _report_driver_status until we send the
capabilities update.  And even if we start the _report_driver_status
task first as soon as it does some I/O to query the backend we'll be
switching to sending the cached data to the schedulers.

It may not sound like a big problem, but when you are quickly creating a
great number of big volumes having an additional minute old data can be
problematic.

This patch changes the way we do the status reporting and ensures that
we are always sending the newest data.

There is only 1 drawback to this change, and that is if a driver takes
longer than 1 minute to gather the stats, because in this case a newly
started scheduler will take a little longer to have stats for this
backend.

Considering the number of times a scheduler service is started versus
the number of stats reports we send it seems like a reasonable
trade-off.

Change-Id: Id203a3a8b8c09e6415dcd26cc5ae684f702b8457
Closes-Bug: #1750878

This patch changes the way we do the status reporting and ensures that
we are always sending the newest data.

There could only be 1 drawback to this change, and that is if a driver
takes longer than 1 minute to gather the stats, because in this case a
newly started scheduler will take a little longer to have stats for this
backend.  But it doesn't really happen, because the schedulers actually
request the volumes for their capabilities on start up.

commit_message:
Fix reporting old stats

For the stats reporting we have a decoupled implementation where the
gathering of stats from the backend and the submission of these stats to
the schedulers are run in independent periodic tasks.

The problem with this implementation is that we'll be getting old stats
all the time because of the threading model we are using.

Since we have greenthreads we will not switch threads until we do I/O,
so if the _publish_service_capabilities periodic task is invoked first
we won't switch to the _report_driver_status until we send the
capabilities update.  And even if we start the _report_driver_status
task first as soon as it does some I/O to query the backend we'll be
switching to sending the cached data to the schedulers.

It may not sound like a big problem, but when you are quickly creating a
great number of big volumes having an additional minute old data can be
problematic.

This patch changes the way we do the status reporting and ensures that
we are always sending the newest data.

There could only be 1 drawback to this change, and that is if a driver
takes longer than 1 minute to gather the stats, because in this case a
newly started scheduler will take a little longer to have stats for this
backend.  But it doesn't really happen, because the schedulers actually
request the volumes for their capabilities on start up.

Change-Id: Id203a3a8b8c09e6415dcd26cc5ae684f702b8457
Closes-Bug: #1750878

commit_message:
BGP service - take logical port info from Neutron DB

When a floating IP is updated, it may be updated before the fixed port
is added to NB api (Due to Neutron's ordering, which is random from our
point of view). Therefore, take the Neutron port from the Neurton DB,
where it should already exist.

Change-Id: Id11a1ad399b107ce8a2ae0469e42c0208d590204
Closes-Bug: #1747423

commit_message:
Fix for timeout=None in orchestration API calls

Our other API calls allow timeout=None to mean "no timeout". Heat does
not have an equivalent for "no timeout", but None will mean to use the
heat server default. Allow for this value in the orchestration calls.

Change-Id: Iae775676e9bb7d3f58d7041537f3a3b15ba52593

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-24 08:19:23.000000000', 'message': "Work around with Devstack multinode gate problem

Multinode job is currently not working. It has several problems which
relate to devstack-gate & devstack procedure. In the legacy multinode gate
setup, devstack-gate writes some more variables in subnode's localrc_file
[1]. These variables will be used in devstack, for example, database [2].
In the Zuulv3 native gate, subnode doesn't get these variables so devstack
mutlinode gate failed.

This patch is just for work around with this problem. We have to change
the procedure if we want to do actual fix.

commit_message:
Work around with Devstack multinode gate problem

Multinode job is currently not working. It has several problems which
relate to devstack-gate & devstack procedure. In the legacy multinode gate
setup, devstack-gate writes some more variables in subnode's localrc_file
[1]. These variables will be used in devstack, for example, database [2].
In the Zuulv3 native gate, subnode doesn't get these variables so devstack
mutlinode job failed.

This patch is just for work around with this problem. We have to change
the procedure if we want to do actual fix.

tls-proxy is disabled for now, as it produces failures in the job.

[1] https://github.com/openstack-infra/devstack-gate/blob/master/devstack-vm-gate.sh#L567-L588
[2] https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/blob/master/lib/database

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/528074
Change-Id: Iae41d6f7baf6f0f781be4eb47a06a64bf66f8dae

- gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario003-multinode-oooq-puppet http://logs.openstack.org/99/467799/2/check/gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario003-multinode-oooq-puppet/f733d03/ : SUCCESS in 1h 55m 18s
- gate-mistral-devstack-dsvm-kombu-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/99/467799/2/check/gate-mistral-devstack-dsvm-kombu-ubuntu-xenial-nv/363ba3e/ : SUCCESS in 37m 55s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-10-18 23:13:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-10-18 23:19:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 16511, 'date': '2017-10-19 02:09:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

- Can the notify input parameter be included in the existing params object, the same way 'env' is handled today?  That would avoid the API/database change and a lot of the interface changes.

- At the PTG we discussed supporting multiple simultaneous plugins using Extensions and passing all events to all extensions, which can decide internally whether they need to do any work, possibly by examining parameters passed in via params"}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-10-20 00:29:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(5 comments)

> Can the notify input parameter be included in the existing params object, the same way 'env' is handled today?

It's possible. But I prefer to be explicit and don't want to abuse env. Plus, it's possible to query for workflow executions with notification specified.

> At the PTG we discussed supporting multiple simultaneous plugins using Extensions and passing all events to all extensions, which can decide internally whether they need to do any work, possibly by examining parameters passed in via params

I only recall support default notifier config specified in the mistral.cfg and allow for workflow level override.  I don't recall agreeing to passing event to ALL extensions. If we want to support multiple notifiers per event, it will have to be explicitly configured.  This patch is getting huge. If we are adding this support, it will be a separate patch."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-10-20 00:36:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Also, I prefer notifiers to be explicitly configured instead of loading ALL extensions and passing ALL events to ALL extensions. The reason is that Mistral is a multi-tenant solution. We can't expect all tenants to use the same set of notifiers. So, there should be a operator level settings in the mistral.cfg to define where the events goes for the operators + workflow level override(s) to define where the events the users want."}, {'account_id': 16511, 'date': '2017-10-23 13:18:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)

> Also, I prefer notifiers to be explicitly configured instead of
 > loading ALL extensions and passing ALL events to ALL extensions.
 > The reason is that Mistral is a multi-tenant solution. We can't
 > expect all tenants to use the same set of notifiers. So, there
 > should be a operator level settings in the mistral.cfg to define
 > where the events goes for the operators + workflow level
 > override(s) to define where the events the users want.

That's fine for multi-tenant, but my deployment is single-tenant and I need ALL events passed to ALL extensions.  I don't want the user to be able to override my settings and I don't want the engine worried about specific notification config that is only needed by the extension."}, {'account_id': 16511, 'date': '2017-10-23 13:21:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> (5 comments)
 > 
 > > Can the notify input parameter be included in the existing params
 > object, the same way 'env' is handled today?
 > 
 > It's possible. But I prefer to be explicit and don't want to abuse
 > env. Plus, it's possible to query for workflow executions with
 > notification specified.
 > 
 > > At the PTG we discussed supporting multiple simultaneous plugins
 > using Extensions and passing all events to all extensions, which
 > can decide internally whether they need to do any work, possibly by
 > examining parameters passed in via params
 > 
 > I only recall support default notifier config specified in the
 > mistral.cfg and allow for workflow level override.  I don't recall
 > agreeing to passing event to ALL extensions. If we want to support
 > multiple notifiers per event, it will have to be explicitly
 > configured.  This patch is getting huge. If we are adding this
 > support, it will be a separate patch.

My recollection of the PTG discussion was that we needed a general solution that had a minimal impact on the engine and allowed for multiple notifiers to receive each event, and then they can decide what to do with the event based on the content of the event context and/or their own configuration.

The scenario I'm trying to solve requires multiple generalized notifiers to receive every event.  Your scenario is very different but can be handled using the same framework if the specifics of your requirements are implemented in your plugin instead of in the engine."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-10-23 16:49:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> That's fine for multi-tenant, but my deployment is single-tenant and I need ALL events passed to ALL extensions.  I don't want the user to be able to override my settings and I don't want the engine worried about specific notification config that is only needed by the extension.

Mistral is a multi-tenant solution by default. I don't think making the notifier implemenation a single-tenant only solution is the right design.

Regardless of what we recall from the PTG, let's go back to the use case. The operator should be able to specify where the events go to. The tenant/user should be able to define there own event consumers. There are many tenants and users each with different preferences. There will be different plugins and some are very generic (i.e. webhook, message queues, etc.).

We cannot assume all events to go to all plugins (or extensions) for a multi-tenant environment. Plus, how do you configure for a generate notifier plugin? Therefore, I think the correct approach is to be explicit and 1) let the operators configure where they want the events to go. 2) let the tenants/users define their own event consumers on workflow execution. There's no conflict here and it makes Mistral much more flexible. Your single tenant use case is still supported, you will just need to configure Mistral correctly. But on the other hand, if all events goes to all plugins, this solution works for single-tenant, but there's no configurable way to make it work for multi-tenant.

On making the plugin filter events, it works if all plugins are tightly defined and customized. But I can see some plugins are very simple and generic like post to webhook or message queues. The filter should not be included in these simple generic notifier plugins. Therefore, I think the filtering should happen server side.  The list of events to be filtered can be configured with the plugin (either in mistral.cfg or provided during workflow execution). If the list is not provided, then the plugin (if specified to receive events) will receive all events."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-10-23 16:55:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

>  I don't want the user to be able to override my settings

Then let whatever the tenant/user specified in the workflow execution just add to the notification list and not override operators settings."}, {'account_id': 27008, 'date': '2017-10-25 09:11:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27008, 'date': '2017-10-25 09:25:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-11-03 03:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-11-03 04:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-11-03 04:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2017-11-22 19:10:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

So, I mostly agree with Bob here. In my opinion, engine should know only about a generic notifier component and the latter should support plugins that can all handle an event in a different way. Maybe at the same time. By default, we could run Mistral with no-op notifier configuration, i.e. no real notifying happens. Lets it make it as flexible as possible. Engine should only have calls to the notifier, w/o knowing about notifier internals and its plugins.

Also, can you please try to make your patches smaller? Even if you are implementing a new feature its always possible to split the entire work into several patches. E.g., notifier class, default no-op notifier plugin, config options (if needed), add calls to engine, basic tests, more advanced tests etc.

Im sure that when people see 1800 lines patch the want to review something else.

Ill come up with a more detailed review soon when I have a chance.'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-11-22 19:50:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> engine should know only about a generic notifier component and the latter should support plugins that can all handle an event in a different way.

Renat, can you provide a concrete example how you will change my implementation?  Currently, the engine's call to notifier is very generic. Check to see if there are notifiers (plugins) configured, then based on the events the notifier configured, instantiate the notifier and notify. It's up to the plugin to deal with the actual call to the 3rd party.

> Also, can you please try to make your patches smaller?

Most of the lines of code are unit tests for coverage. The actual code for the notifier function is actually not that huge and essential for a commit that implements the function end to end."}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2017-12-13 09:47:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

I did a more thorough review. Please see my comments. From the user standpoint, I think the biggest thing is the lack of a flexible subscription mechanism. I realize that it's a big design change but I'm sure we need to design it now and cover more cases, e.g. when we don't want to subscribe for a specific workflow execution and want to receive a stream of events regardless of workflow executions."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-01-03 23:26:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(10 comments)

Let's get on the same page on the terms. To me, the notifier plugins are event publishers (not subscribers). Mistral should just publish the events and that's it and don't need to care about individual subscribers. For example, the plugin could be publishing to a zaqar queue or a webhook API into another system with many other subscribers define there. On flexibility, I plan to add a config section to define one or more event publishers for all events. And on each workflow execution, the notify param allows additional event publishers to be included dynamically in addition to the static list of default publishers defined in the config section."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-02 01:26:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-07 19:37:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-07 22:53:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 16511, 'date': '2018-02-09 16:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Overall it looks good, my only suggestion would be to move the for loop for the different notifications into the notification server so the engine/executor just needs to make one RPC call per event instead of one per event/notification type.  The notification server can loop through all of the notifications for each event and process them.'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-09 19:43:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16511, 'date': '2018-02-09 20:21:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-09 22:35:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-09 22:36:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-10 04:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 16511, 'date': '2018-02-10 15:09:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

Thanks Winson.  LGTM.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-02-17 12:56:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2

(3 comments)

A few minor things but generally looks good!'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-02-18 10:26:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)

Just one more comment. I don't want to block this patch anyway since I think this comment is not something critical, maybe just something we could slightly improve.

Also one more question: just intuitively, I still would like to see some new endpoint on the REST API that I as a user could use to subscribe to needed events. Ee.g. I want to get all events of type WORKFLOW_FAILED which is pretty easy to understand why.. Do I understand you right that you assume that if such an API is needed it can be just a special publisher that has this kind of mechanism that allows clients to subscribe on events? On one hand I agree and it may be OK but it still feels like this could be a natural part of the Mistral REST API.

Let's elaborate more on that please."}, {'account_id': 15895, 'date': '2018-02-20 09:50:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

LGTM but I've not tested it. Lacks documentation"}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-02-20 13:07:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Yes, in order to make it a usable feature we'll need to document it well."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-20 23:15:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Thanks! I'll work on the docs next."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-22 18:30:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2018-02-22 20:25:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-02-22 20:32:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Workflow-1

commit_message:
Implement notification of execution events

Introduce execution events and notification server and plugins for
publishing these events for consumers. Event notification is defined per
workflow execution and can be configured to notify on all the events or
only for specific events.

Change-Id: I9820bdc4792a374dad9ad5310f84cd7aaddab8ca
Implements: blueprint mistral-execution-event-subscription

commit_message:
Fix coverage running

The post coverage job fails, fix invocation - this is not shade but
openstacksdk.

Prior to this change, running tox -e cover resulted in:
...
Coverage.py warning: Module shade was never imported.
(module-not-imported)
Coverage.py warning: No data was collected. (no-data-collected)

Change-Id: I920fee18083d41d0938bbe19b4b7cf7759aece0c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-23 22:13:41.000000000', 'message': "Don't use sitepackages for cli target

It fails on fedora25 with system gssapi package installed with the
following error:

AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'GSSException'

It happens because of: https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/issues/584
that will be fixed with https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/pull/861
that is not released or even merged yet.

It's better to isolate the venv from system libraries that may be
incompatible with paramiko.

Change-Id: I98af75bb01fa42a2902a850de1b974abc982d432
"}]
commit_message:
Don't use sitepackages for cli target

It fails on fedora25 with system gssapi package installed with the
following error:

AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'GSSException'

It happens because of: https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/issues/584
that will be fixed with https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/pull/861
that is not released or even merged yet.

It's better to isolate the venv from system libraries that may be
incompatible with paramiko.

Change-Id: I98af75bb01fa42a2902a850de1b974abc982d432

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-22 19:50:43.000000000', 'message': '[db] Rework 7287df262dbc migration

Rally <0.10.0 was hardcoded to support only OpenStack platform. That is
why deployment config had a flat schema (i.e openstack credentials were
at the same top-level as other properties).

Rally 0.10 includes an attempt to unify deployment component for
supporting multiple platforms. The deployment config was extended with a
new top level property `creds` which was designed to include credentials
for different platforms.
Since Task and Verification components used deployment.credentials object
from database instead of using deployment config directly, Rally 0.10 did
not provide a database migration of deployment config.

While developing Rally 0.11.0 with new Environment component, we made a
wrong assumption and forgot about an old format. That is why a
7287df262dbc migration relied on "creds" property of deployment.config

If the database was created before Rally<0.10, the introduced assumption
leds to KeyError failure[0] for old deployment configuration:

  File ".../7287df262dbc_move_deployment_to_env.py", line 137, in upgrade
       and (set(spec["creds"]) == {"openstack"}
  KeyError: 'creds'

To fix this issue, we need to disable 7287df262dbc migration, introduce
a new migration for an old deployment format, return the code of
7287df262dbc in a new migration.

Change-Id: I475fd1b0f14af923552d92da87df09c26b81bb7a
'}, {'created': '2018-02-22 20:00:46.000000000', 'message': '[db] Rework 7287df262dbc migration

new top level property `creds` which was designed to include credentials
for different platforms.
Since Task and Verification components used deployment.credentials object
from database instead of using deployment config directly, Rally 0.10 did
not provide a database migration of deployment config.

While developing Rally 0.11.0 with new Environment component, we made a
wrong assumption and forgot about an old format. That is why a
7287df262dbc migration relied on "creds" property of deployment.config

If the database was created before Rally<0.10, the introduced assumption
leds to KeyError failure[0] for old deployment configuration:

  File ".../7287df262dbc_move_deployment_to_env.py", line 137, in upgrade
       and (set(spec["creds"]) == {"openstack"}
  KeyError: 'creds'

To fix this issue, we need to disable 7287df262dbc migration, introduce
a new migration for an old deployment format, return the code of
7287df262dbc in a new migration.

NOTE: This commit introduces several migrations at once. These
   migrations have downgrade methods which are not tested(we do not support
   downgrade, but these methods are mandatory). To make CI happy with these
   uncovered by unit tests lines we need to temporary increase the magic
   number in coverage job.

Change-Id: I475fd1b0f14af923552d92da87df09c26b81bb7a

commit_message:
[db] Rework 7287df262dbc migration

Rally <0.10.0 was hardcoded to support only OpenStack platform. That is
why deployment config had a flat schema (i.e openstack credentials were
at the same top-level as other properties).

Rally 0.10 includes an attempt to unify deployment component for
supporting multiple platforms. The deployment config was extended with a
new top level property `creds` which was designed to include credentials
for different platforms.
Since Task and Verification components used deployment.credentials object
from database instead of using deployment config directly, Rally 0.10 did
not provide a database migration of deployment config.

While developing Rally 0.11.0 with new Environment component, we made a
wrong assumption and forgot about an old format. That is why a
7287df262dbc migration relied on "creds" property of deployment.config

If the database was created before Rally<0.10, the introduced assumption
leds to KeyError failure[0] for old deployment configuration:

  File ".../7287df262dbc_move_deployment_to_env.py", line 137, in upgrade
       and (set(spec["creds"]) == {"openstack"}
  KeyError: 'creds'

To fix this issue, we need to disable 7287df262dbc migration, introduce
a new migration for an old deployment format, return the code of
7287df262dbc in a new migration.

NOTE: This commit introduces several migrations at once. These
   migrations have downgrade methods which are not tested(we do not support
   downgrade, but these methods are mandatory). To make CI happy with these
   uncovered by unit tests lines we need to temporary increase the magic
   number in coverage job.

Change-Id: I475fd1b0f14af923552d92da87df09c26b81bb7a

subject: Fix race condition on ovn_client on startup
messages: [{'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2018-02-23 11:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2018-02-23 13:22:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nThanks for backporting it!'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2018-02-24 23:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-23 11:12:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix race condition on ovn_client on startup

On startup, when we initialize the IDL we start receiving notifications
right away and processing them. There's a possibility that even though
the IDLs are initialized, post_fork_initialize has not yet created the
ovn_client object resulting in an exception (and also possible missing
DB updates) if attempted to be used.

This patch fixes this by converting ovn_client object in mech driver
into a property which initializes it if doesn't exist yet.

Change-Id: I3965ae61fb5ba7dda07bb797a09383a6c35f589e
Closes-Bug: #1731288
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 48e9101d6850de63ae3c4a117c13876c47392006)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix race condition on ovn_client on startup

On startup, when we initialize the IDL we start receiving notifications
right away and processing them. There's a possibility that even though
the IDLs are initialized, post_fork_initialize has not yet created the
ovn_client object resulting in an exception (and also possible missing
DB updates) if attempted to be used.

This patch fixes this by converting ovn_client object in mech driver
into a property which initializes it if doesn't exist yet.

Change-Id: I3965ae61fb5ba7dda07bb797a09383a6c35f589e
Closes-Bug: #1731288
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 48e9101d6850de63ae3c4a117c13876c47392006)

messages: [{'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2018-02-23 11:09:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2018-02-23 13:23:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nThanks for backporting it!'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2018-02-24 23:44:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-23 11:09:49.000000000', 'message': "Initialize privsep in networking-ovn-metadata-agent

We were not initializing privsep in the metadata agent so we weren't
using any root helper to call it. In devstack this is not a problem
since 'stack' user can execute anything but in TripleO deployments
it won't work since user 'neutron' is only allowed to execute commands
through rootwrap/rootwrap-daemon. This patch initializes privsep which
whatever root_helper is configured.

Change-Id: I8b1552f5adfef4f3fb114445b463a4c77b25ac9c
Closes-Bug: #1737587
(cherry picked from commit 688c34a2dd0f6ab25a3f295a9c5e39522cbb4c7e)
"}]
commit_message:
Initialize privsep in networking-ovn-metadata-agent

We were not initializing privsep in the metadata agent so we weren't
using any root helper to call it. In devstack this is not a problem
since 'stack' user can execute anything but in TripleO deployments
it won't work since user 'neutron' is only allowed to execute commands
through rootwrap/rootwrap-daemon. This patch initializes privsep which
whatever root_helper is configured.

Change-Id: I8b1552f5adfef4f3fb114445b463a4c77b25ac9c
Closes-Bug: #1737587
(cherry picked from commit 688c34a2dd0f6ab25a3f295a9c5e39522cbb4c7e)

subject: dependencies: move dynamic common deps under a 'dynamic.common' key
messages:
[{'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-23 18:55:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-24 01:05:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

This ps uses dynamic.common; what does the "common" indicate and what's the alternative?'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-24 22:40:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-24 22:42:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-24 22:42:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-24 22:48:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > This ps uses dynamic.common; what does the "common" indicate and
 > what's the alternative?

The alternative would be targeting deps to pods conditionally, using neutron as an example:
```
dependencies:
  dynamic:
    common:
      local_image_registry:
        jobs:
          - neutron-image-repo-sync
        services:
          - endpoint: node
            service: local_image_registry
    targeted:
      linuxbridge:
        dhcp:
          daemonset:
            - neutron-lb-agent
        l3:
          daemonset:
            - neutron-lb-agent
        metadata:
          daemonset:
            - neutron-lb-agent
      openvswitch:
        dhcp:
          daemonset:
            - neutron-ovs-agent
        l3:
          daemonset:
            - neutron-ovs-agent
        metadata:
          daemonset:
            - neutron-ovs-agent
  static:
    bootstrap:
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: network
        - endpoint: internal
          service: compute
    db_drop:
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_db
    db_init:
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_db
    db_sync:
      jobs:
        - neutron-db-init
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_db
    dhcp:
      daemonset: null
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_messaging
        - endpoint: internal
          service: network
        - endpoint: internal
          service: compute
    ks_endpoints:
      jobs:
        - neutron-ks-service
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: identity
    ks_service:
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: identity
    ks_user:
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: identity
    l3:
      daemonset: null
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_messaging
        - endpoint: internal
          service: network
        - endpoint: internal
          service: compute
    lb_agent:
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_messaging
        - endpoint: internal
          service: network
    metadata:
      daemonset: null
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_messaging
        - endpoint: internal
          service: network
        - endpoint: internal
          service: compute
        - endpoint: public
          service: compute_metadata
    ovs_agent:
      daemonset:
        - openvswitch-vswitchd
        - openvswitch-db
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_messaging
        - endpoint: internal
          service: network
    server:
      jobs:
        - neutron-db-sync
        - neutron-ks-user
        - neutron-ks-endpoints
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_db
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_messaging
        - endpoint: internal
          service: oslo_cache
        - endpoint: internal
          service: identity
    tests:
      services:
        - endpoint: internal
          service: network
        - endpoint: internal
          service: compute
```'}, {'account_id': 22477, 'date': '2018-02-25 00:18:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25731, 'date': '2018-02-25 00:39:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-02-25 00:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

dependencies: move dynamic common deps under a 'dynamic.common' key

This PS moves existing dynamic common dependencies under a
'dynamic.common' key to simplify the yaml tree.

commit_message:
Add support for endpoint group commands

Implements the commands for endpoint group filter management.
Includes the CRUD management of the endpoint groups and the
association management between them and the projects that are
using this method.

Implements: blueprint keystone-endpoint-filter
Change-Id: I4265f7f8598d028191e90d76781b7b6ece6fef64

commit_message:
Add project tags functionality

This change adds tags functionality for projects in keystone. A user
can add a single tag with "--tag", chain "--tag" to add multiple
tags, or clear tags with "--no-tag".

Change-Id: I31cfef3e76dcefe299dacb00c11bb1a10a252628
Partially-Implements: bp project-tags

commit_message:
Update rabbitmq dashboard to support multiple deployments

Adds the necessary changes to allow grafana to display metrics for
multiple rabbitmq-exporter deployments, in the cases where
multiple rabbitmq instances are deployed

Change-Id: Ie2bef28e0428870e529d71717c9eeea51ac445aa
