subject: Create Keystone V3 Deployment Class
messages:
[{'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-16 00:55:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:34:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-16 22:49:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-16 23:05:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-17 00:23:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-17 02:23:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-19 20:19:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-20 22:25:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 27801, 'date': '2018-02-21 19:48:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

KeystoneV3Deployment subclass is being used here to essentially blacklist identity v2 tests by forcing them to run with a v3 client. 

This works for the imminent charm release (and is understandable), but I think it's going to be new technical debt to address later.

IMO, the correct design for these amulet tests is to have a pool of test functions and then have separate selection logic which determines which tests to run based on the test profile i.e. OpenStack release. For example if Queens is under test, we wouldn't select any identity v2 tests to run.

What may be more in line with this approach (without refactoring) would be to add 'if self.is_pike_or_older():' clauses to identity v2 tests instead of subclassing (and fits with existing such clauses on other tests)."}, {'account_id': 20635, 'date': '2018-02-21 21:41:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I believe that it is Amulet itself (not our helpers) which does the test selection (test_.*), so we would have to modify that project in order to achieve a more sane selection approach.  I agree with the pool of tests, and selection sentiment.  That is exactly what we will get when we switch to using subsets of tempest tests.

I'm not in favor of a refactor of these legacy Amulet helpers, as they will be ripped out entirely within the next cycle and replaced with a more modular approach of [libjuju] + [zaza] + [a pool of tests/tempest].

In-line release conditionals are indeed the established precedent in the amulet tests.  This subclass approach is cleaner in some ways and more complex in other ways.  The in-line conditionals can get quite difficult to track, whereas the subclass approach is clear in that you know the entire method is replaced, and probably with a much more simple one.

Keep in mind also that we've discussed and decided that it is only the keystone charm's tests which should test keystone explicitly.  

When we get to updating the other charms, I am in favor of dropping explicit keystone tests which are not unique to the charm (cinder, for example, doesn't need to walk and verify the whole catalog of endpoints in keystone).  We have shown that those tests are too brittle in practice and really only result in blocking people, rather than catching meaningful bugs.

All in all, I'm in favor of a tastefully tactical fix, knowing that this entire /tests/ directory is essentially technical debt.  ;-)

I'd like to have another core charmer weigh in as well.  Thank you all for your work on this."}, {'account_id': 20635, 'date': '2018-02-21 21:45:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-02-21 22:59:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

The gerrit interface rapidly becomes untenable. Sorry for the mess, but context is critical. Many API calls change when keystone defaults to v3.

@Robert
> KeystoneV3Deployment subclass is being used here to essentially blacklist identity v2 tests by forcing them to run with a v3 client. 
This is not quite correct. The tests are still need to occur but the client inputs and outputs can be radically different. We are not skipping them. What is new is as of queens we are not jumping from v2 to v3. It remains at v3 throughout.

> This works for the imminent charm release (and is understandable), but I think it's going to be new technical debt to address later.
See Ryan's response, this is all technical debt.

> IMO, the correct design for these amulet tests is to have a pool of test functions and then have separate selection logic which determines which tests to run based on the test profile i.e. OpenStack release. For example if Queens is under test, we wouldn't select any identity v2 tests to run.
Again, we still need to run the tests. They are just different.

> What may be more in line with this approach (without refactoring) would be to add 'if self.is_pike_or_older():' clauses to identity v2 tests instead of subclassing (and fits with existing such clauses on other tests).
We could make an argument for test_n is v2 and test_n+1 is v3 but I don't think that is as clean.


@Ryan
...
> Keep in mind also that we've discussed and decided that it is only the keystone charm's tests which should test keystone explicitly.  

> When we get to updating the other charms, I am in favor of dropping explicit keystone tests which are not unique to the charm (cinder, for example, doesn't need to walk and verify the whole catalog of endpoints in keystone).  We have shown that those tests are too brittle in practice and really only result in blocking people, rather than catching meaningful bugs.

I agree will be removing the keystone or catalog specific tests but this affects more than just client acquisition. There are times when the test needs to consult the catalog for some subsequent purpose. I need to get you more science on this but nova-cc should be an example.


> I'd like to have another core charmer weigh in as well.  Thank you all for your work on this.
Agreed.

My argument is that we will need to make fairly dramatic changes to most if not all charms. Keystone being the most affected. I am aware of the fact this is technical debt but it has to be addressed. I'll wait to hear more input."}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2018-02-22 16:54:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

We know this is tech debt; but I think it's pragmatic to let it though now and deal with it by dropping all of the /tests/ as Ryan indicated at *some* point in the future!"}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-02-23 16:29:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

I agree with tinwood, lgtm and lets accept the tech debt'}]

commit_message:
Create Keystone V3 Deployment Class

For Queens keystone v2 has been dropped. V3 is the only valid API
version. The charm has already made this change. This change is to
bring the amulet test up to match by creating a separate class.

Charm-helpers sync

Enlarging the amulet timeout value.

Change-Id: I822624bdf45bfb060dd75ba3b10e71984bc10e48

commit_message:
Fix cache update after initial apt_repository fail

If apt_repository fails to update the apt cache after updating the
configuration, retries don't register there was a change and so no
attempt is made to update the cache by the module on the second attempt.
This failure can result in a failure to install packages.

This change adds an apt module task to update the cache if the
apt_repository task registers a change. This means updating the cache
will get retried on failure and no longer fail silently.

Change-Id: I3a346bec7b5656d780416054fbaa6e322b6216f2
Partial-Bug: #1750656
(cherry picked from commit c68db4e674e744f4e75841de801731f3de5da8fa)

commit_message:
ffu: Introduce Keystone fast-forward upgrade tasks

fast_forward_upgrade_tasks for keystone covering Ocata and Pike.
- Service status check
- Stop service when updating from Ocata to Pike
- Update keystone package
- Db sync

bp fast-forward-upgrades
Change-Id: I65b0c562c6e2545e99e9511d7b148c2130cc6b25

[{'created': '2018-02-23 08:34:50.000000000', 'message': 'upgrade-non-controller.sh script does not support alternative plan names

This patch adds a new parameter to configure the plan name when
executing the "openstack overcloud config download" command.

The default plan is as usual 'overcloud'.

Change-Id: Icf5eb530b44553e3a79f6e0b7859b46ef08cc926
Closes-Bug: 1750338
Resolves: rhbz#1545415
(cherry picked from commit 971bc3298d56d9c1df0044e35ae68e92f7aa8895)
'}]
commit_message:
upgrade-non-controller.sh script does not support alternative plan names

This patch adds a new parameter to configure the plan name when
executing the "openstack overcloud config download" command.

The default plan is as usual 'overcloud'.

Change-Id: Icf5eb530b44553e3a79f6e0b7859b46ef08cc926
Closes-Bug: 1750338
Resolves: rhbz#1545415
(cherry picked from commit 971bc3298d56d9c1df0044e35ae68e92f7aa8895)

commit_message:
Store ansible playbooks output to log files for FFU

This change stores the FFU ansible playbooks to log files so they
can be easily retrieved during artifacts collection. In addition
this change moves the ansible playbook commands into shell scripts.

Change-Id: I9234f1a677b2f0c034a0d54b9e1ea77377f03093

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-21 16:18:52.000000000', 'message': "Regex gerritbot notifications: #openstack-ansible

Since [1] we support regular expressions syntax in channel configuration
YAML files for the gerritbot.

This patch applies regexes for the channel listed in the title to:
- reduce the size and improve readability of the paragraph
- eliminate the need for subsequent patches as new stable/* branches are
  published.

Note that we're not bothering to exclude old/EOL stable branches.  The
philosophy here is that notifications for those branches should almost
never happen anyway; and if they do, you want to know about them.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/499367

Change-Id: I10761f06d216e0f9404a26f816b18952147b6858
"}, {'created': '2018-02-21 16:24:51.000000000', 'message': 'Regex gerritbot notifications: #fuel-tracker

Since [1] we support regular expressions syntax in channel configuration
YAML files for the gerritbot.

This patch applies regexes for the channel listed in the title to reduce
the size and improve readability of the paragraph.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/499367

Change-Id: I10761f06d216e0f9404a26f816b18952147b6858
'}]
commit_message:
Regex gerritbot notifications: #fuel-tracker

Since [1] we support regular expressions syntax in channel configuration
YAML files for the gerritbot.

This patch applies regexes for the channel listed in the title to reduce
the size and improve readability of the paragraph.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/499367

Change-Id: I10761f06d216e0f9404a26f816b18952147b6858

Update bot for puppet-openstack to include Queens

Now that stable/queens has been created, we need to add it to the list for
the bot to report on in irc.

Change-Id: I18cff95bf731effe4c094508b681bc599ed564ea

Add stable branch notification for openstack-cinder

Taking advantage of the new regex capability to have stable branch
activity announced for cinder repos.

commit_message:
Add test for tempest run with a whitelist file

This commit adds a functional test for tempest run with the
--whitelist-file flag to the tempest unit test suite. This will verify
that the whitelist-file argument is being honored correctly and only the
tests matching the regexes in there are being run.

Change-Id: I1935d26ba2a6f761cb2cdc6a129a0008659cad13

commit_message:
Add a black_regex flag to tempest run

Now that we're using stestr internally the selection regex is more
sophisticated, and lets you exclude on match from a cli regex too. To
leverage this functionality this commit adds a new cli argument to
use it.

Change-Id: I440ab90f576e1ac333c7c40175ad6117d1299c04

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 09:48:25.000000000', 'message': 'Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ib7cffd1b06b81c0c31fd2f6f3894d3810117cea9
'}]
commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ib7cffd1b06b81c0c31fd2f6f3894d3810117cea9

commit_message:
Fix the -l/--list-tests argument for tempest run

The tempest run to stestr migration accidently removed the list command.
This commit adds the functionality back and adds a unit test to ensure
this doesn't happen in the future.

Change-Id: Ibc74887dec98f5d9adce56c235d28b19d0a94a63

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-22 18:04:57.000000000', 'message': "WIP shrink final shard range to root container

TODO: this gets to a state where the root has the remaining objects in
its own db and all shards are retired, but currently the root still
considers itself to be sharded so doe snto look in its own db for
objects. We need to return the root to unsharded state, which ahs
implications for its db naming.

When a container has only a single shard range and its size is below
the shrining threshold, cause it to cleave its contents to the root.

This means that a deleted container (by definition empty) will
eventually have no shard ranges, which means that it can be cleaned up
independently of any historic shard containers.  Without this we'd
need to synchronously check the root's final shard range before
cleaning up the root, and such checks are prone to shard containers
being temporarily unavailable.

This also means that all shard containers will be 'retired' before we
need to make a decision to delete them, so we don't need to worry
about their sharding sysmeta being lost on deletion.

Change-Id: If5b5ad2457f831a4368283d05812b25e50b080b9

"}, {'created': '2018-02-20 22:55:14.000000000', 'message': "WIP shrink final shard range to root container

When a container has only a single shard range and its size is below
the shrinking threshold, cause it to cleave its contents to the root.

This means that a deleted container (by definition empty) will
eventually have no shard ranges, which means that it can be cleaned up
independently of any historic shard containers. Also, all shard
containers whose root is deleted (and by definition empty) will
eventually reach sharded state (since they will all have been shrunk
away) and that can be used to infer that they can be cleaned up after,
for example, reclaim_age.

Without this we'd need to synchronously check the root's final shard
range before cleaning up the root, and such checks are prone to shard
containers being temporarily unavailable.

This also means that all shard containers will be 'retired' before we
need to make a decision to delete them, so we don't need to worry
about their sharding sysmeta being lost on deletion.

Change-Id: If5b5ad2457f831a4368283d05812b25e50b080b9
"}, {'created': '2018-02-21 15:52:48.000000000', 'message': "Shrink final shard range to root container

When a container has only a single shard range and its size is below
the shrinking threshold, cause it to cleave its contents to the root.

* The rows of the shard range are sync'd to the root container shard db.
* The final shard range is deleted from the root shard_ranges table.
* The root transitions to an unsharded state.
* If the root grows in size again, it shards again to new shard
  containers.

This means that a deleted container (by definition empty) will
eventually have no shard ranges, which means that it can be cleaned up
independently of any historic shard containers. Also, all shard
containers whose root is deleted (and by definition empty) will
eventually reach sharded state (since they will all have been shrunk
away) and that can be used to infer that they can be cleaned up after,
for example, reclaim_age.

Without this we'd need to synchronously check the root's final shard
range before cleaning up the root, and such checks are prone to shard
containers being temporarily unavailable.

This also means that all shard containers will be 'retired' before we
need to make a decision to delete them, so we don't need to worry
about their sharding sysmeta being lost on deletion.

To facilitate this the naming of db files has changed. Before, a
<hash>_shard.db file was created when sharding a <hash>.db. This
can only be done once. Now, a <hash>_epoch.db file is created
when sharding a <hash>.db, where epoch is a Timestamp string.
Then, a <hash>_newer_epoch.db can be created if <hash>_epoch.db
needs to be sharded again.

Change-Id: If5b5ad2457f831a4368283d05812b25e50b080b9

commit_message:
Shrink final shard range to root container

When a container has only a single shard range and its size is below
the shrinking threshold, cause it to cleave its contents to the root.

* The rows of the shard range are sync'd to the root container shard db.
* The final shard range is deleted from the root shard_ranges table.
* The root transitions to an unsharded state.
* If the root grows in size again, it shards again to new shard
  containers.

This means that a deleted container (by definition empty) will
eventually have no shard ranges, which means that it can be cleaned up
independently of any historic shard containers. Also, all shard
containers whose root is deleted (and by definition empty) will
eventually reach sharded state (since they will all have been shrunk
away) and that can be used to infer that they can be cleaned up after,
for example, reclaim_age.

Without this we'd need to synchronously check the root's final shard
range before cleaning up the root, and such checks are prone to shard
containers being temporarily unavailable.

This also means that all shard containers will be 'retired' before we
need to make a decision to delete them, so we don't need to worry
about their sharding sysmeta being lost on deletion.

To facilitate this the naming of db files has changed. Before, a
<hash>_shard.db file was created when sharding a <hash>.db. This
can only be done once. Now, a <hash>_epoch.db file is created
when sharding a <hash>.db, where epoch is a Timestamp string.
Then, a <hash>_newer_epoch.db can be created if <hash>_epoch.db
needs to be sharded again.

Change-Id: If5b5ad2457f831a4368283d05812b25e50b080b9

[{'created': '2018-02-23 07:33:52.000000000', 'message': "Rename API_TIMEOUT and API_PARALLEL vars

API_TIMEOUT and API_PARALLEL, both of them are for template generator
and the naming looks too generic.  This is not good because they will be
global under django.  It's better to  rename them to indicate both
parameters for heat-dashboard.

commit_message:
Rename API_TIMEOUT and API_PARALLEL vars

API_TIMEOUT and API_PARALLEL, both of them are for template generator
and the naming looks too generic.  This is not good because they will be
global under django.  It's better to  rename them to indicate both
parameters for heat-dashboard.

Change-Id: I1ad610fd796d158174ae9cb855bd5d8da72bc1f8
Closes-Bug: #1750930

commit_message:
Make tempest jobs voting

These jobs were disabled because of a high failure rate. As a result of
this the jobs got neglected. Now we migrated the jobs to Zuul v3 and we
should now focus on fixing breakages. Therefore, this patchs makes them
enabled so attention is paid to them and also they act as gates for new
patches.

Change-Id: Ieb28c45757818747edd3ffbba3a97e680171172e

commit_message:
[WIP] Remove CI timeout from devstackgaterc

With Zuul v3 the timeout is defined as part of the job itself, therefore
this is not needed anymore.

Change-Id: I7bfdb322de7ad27cb5ad1d8e1dcd457720aa74b7

I'm referring to these other two patches along this one.

commit_message:
Stop using --os-baremetal-api-version in devstack by default

We're defaulting to 'latest' in ironicclient now, so only use
it if IRONIC_DEFAULT_API_VERSION is overriden.

Change-Id: Ifa813a9f0980e7d9c65166ef288d0c6f273ba521

subject: Return old ranges to network_data.yaml
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6133, 'name': 'yolanda.robla', 'email': 'yroblamo@redhat.com', 'username': 'yolanda.robla'}, {'_account_id': 6681, 'name': 'Brent Eagles', 'email': 'beagles@redhat.com', 'username': 'beagles'}, {'_account_id': 8042, 'name': 'Ji Strnsk', 'email': 'jistr@redhat.com', 'username': 'jistr'}, {'_account_id': 8297, 'name': 'Sofer Athlan-Guyot', 'email': 'sathlang@redhat.com', 'username': 'chem'}, {'_account_id': 11166, 'name': 'Lukas Bezdicka', 'email': 'social@v3.sk', 'username': 'xbezdick'}, {'_account_id': 12398, 'name': 'Dan Sneddon', 'email': 'dsneddon@redhat.com', 'username': 'dsneddon'}, {'_account_id': 18575, 'name': 'Saravanan KR', 'email': 'krsacme@gmail.com', 'username': 'saravanankr'}, {'_account_id': 18851, 'name': 'Marius Cornea', 'email': 'mcornea@redhat.com', 'username': 'mcornea'}, {'_account_id': 20775, 'name': 'Carlos Camacho', 'email': 'ccamacho@redhat.com', 'username': 'ccamacho'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2018-02-21 15:25:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2018-02-21 15:41:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Waiting for ci, but lgtm.  Can't see why it would be necessary to change those values, so reverting to their previous default seems to make sense."}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-02-21 15:51:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I agree, this change is really dangerous for minor update/major upgrades.'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2018-02-21 15:58:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

The reasoning makes sense. I quickly browsed the review comments on the original change and didn't find any discussion on why the ranges changed (around ps 29 or 30?). Considering the possibility that there was a strong use case, I think we should get Dan's feedback before this is merged."}, {'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2018-02-22 11:55:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-02-22 11:57:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2018-02-22 12:09:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-02-22 14:27:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2018-02-22 14:28:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-02-22 19:48:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The reason for the IP range changes is to support routed spine-and-leaf. If there is a local set of networks in each rack with routing between them, then we need a way to route traffic between the subnets. For instance, when a compute in Rack B contacts a controller in Rack A, we want the outbound traffic to use the local Internal API network in rack B, and we want the return traffic to use the Internal API network in rack A. To achieve this, both networks need a route to the same supernet. Having all Internal API networks under the same /16 supernet allows each rack to have a route to 172.16.0.0/16 that uses the local 172.16.X.0/24 network gateway.

I hadn't expected that this would affect upgrades, because I thought that all CI testing used custom network addresses, rather than the defaults. The solution here is to not use the defaults, and instead use a custom network-environment.yaml that sets the actual networks that should be used.

If we have to revert this, that's fine, but we should fix CI so that it is not affected by changing the defaults in the sample templates (which are, after all, supposed to be just examples)."}, {'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2018-02-23 12:22:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I tried to look at this from several angles but this probably wins - if someone deployed with defaults at any point they should not change or break. We either introduce the change that saves network config from swift and reuses it so we can change the default or we just keep it carved in stone. We could introduce new network environment example to use the support of routed spine-and-leaf.'}, {'account_id': 20775, 'date': '2018-02-23 12:25:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-02-23 12:32:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow+1

Yea i see both sides of the coin. Looking at docs it doesn't seem to imply that users can't use those default ranges, which means any change in them would have to be explicitly addressed.

For backwards incompatible changes like these, it's possible to put an env file into t-h-t/environments/updates which allows users to carry on with old defaults. There are already files in there which can be used as an example.

So we'd first need to put in the file, then change CI to use it, and then switch to the new defaults, and make sure that usage of the env file is documented for upgrades from older versions.

The best solution for now seems to be to undo the breaking change, at least temporarily."}]

commit_message:
Return old ranges to network_data.yaml

In change 'Render NIC config templates with jinja2' there was also
change of IP ranges for networks. This change is backwards
incompatible and it's better to revert the ranges instead of making
compatibility workaround.

Change-Id: Ifd9f4abaf8b9ac18c251ab8cfba326f2fa92f796

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I823fec50e980447bcb071169c5b25fb2c9d6575b

[{'created': '2018-02-23 00:30:15.000000000', 'message': "Add an exec to adjust iptables

Use an exec to adjust the FORWARD rule for iptables because docker will
change it when it runs which is during a puppet run. The puppet run
won't know to change the default policy until the second run.

Change-Id: I0f28a01ee0d2ca2025c3ef3319d85ace735e7c60
Related-Bug: #1740874
Related-Bug: #1750194
"}]
commit_message:
Add an exec to adjust iptables

Use an exec to adjust the FORWARD rule for iptables because docker will
change it when it runs which is during a puppet run. The puppet run
won't know to change the default policy until the second run.

Change-Id: I0f28a01ee0d2ca2025c3ef3319d85ace735e7c60
Related-Bug: #1740874
Related-Bug: #1750194

commit_message:
Ensure docker starts before firewallchains run

Docker messes with the firewall chains when it executes so lets see if
by ensuring the service runs prior to the firewallchain resource if
it'll manage it properly.

Change-Id: I90059281e7174bb04a814941c5f173287bbb170d
Related-Bug: #1750194
Related-Bug: #1750874

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-05 23:08:37.000000000', 'message': "Add VERBOSE_NO_TIMESTAMP flag

As described in the documentation, this flag is intended for the case
where the console output is being captured by a tool that appends its
own timestamps.

In the gate this is the job-output.txt.  We want the console output as
people like to watch that scrolling by as part of the live console
log.  Although this gets saved to job-output.txt, we still want to
keep logging to the individual log files even though it's technically

commit_message:
Add VERBOSE_NO_TIMESTAMP flag

As described in the documentation, this flag is intended for the case
where the console output is being captured by a tool that appends its
own timestamps.

In the gate this is the job-output.txt.  We want the console output as
people like to watch that scrolling by as part of the live console
log.  Although this gets saved to job-output.txt, we still want to
keep logging to the individual log files even though it's technically
a duplicate -- in the multinode case the job-output.txt gets
interleaved by all the running nodes; it's much easier to just look at
the individual log files.  Also, people are used to it where it is :)

Change-Id: I3486636f1c76139581f6cd9668426f507b7c621d

commit_message:
py3 changes for outfilter.py

I started running this with dib where we have pure python3
environments and it failed.

You can't have unbuffered text i/o in python3 for ... reasons? [1]
Changing the file to binary mode works around this.  Python3 opens
sys.stdin in text mode, so we need to manually convert the unicode
strings to bytes before we write them to the binary file.

[1] http://bugs.python.org/issue17404

Change-Id: Iebb26f0d3c2347d262cbc10dfd0912840cd05878

commit_message:
Fix functional tests by using ovs with commit 8b70d82461ea104858ebd7d397ec004f6974240b

Use branch 2.9. The commit 8bf332225d4a73f359c806ad907bcb78ad2a6087
- "ovn-northd: Reduce amount of flow hashing." in ovs master has caused
regressions because of which functional tests are failing. So use the commit
8b70d82461ea104858ebd7d397ec004f6974240b.
We can revert back to master, once the regressions are addressed.

Change-Id: Ic50865033088443769442667385ed303624e7691
Closes-bug: #1750599

commit_message:
Drop unnecessary dependencies from role

The role currently installs debhelper and dh-apparmor which are
not used and cruft from years ago.  It's causing issues with the
UCA Queens repos so removing them fixes the gate and speeds up
installs.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/547139
Change-Id: I7db925044993d1f45a4a6827eec134ad51a04f54

commit_message:
Specify grafana version

Currently grafana has no version, cluster use grafana:latest.
But the 'GF_DASHBOARDS_JSON_PATH' is invalid in grafana:latest.
So let's specify 4.6.3.

Change-Id: I4dbbe433cff42a25d6b27c25cdba06ef3aee8103

[{'created': '2018-02-21 18:57:34.000000000', 'message': 'Make sharded shards report zero object stats

Before, when a container had been sharded, its object stats (as

With this patchset this is only done if the container is the root

Change-Id: I766de4977e2b766d511545299777f06908a7c0c2

Change-Id: I766de4977e2b766d511545299777f06908a7c0c2

commit_message:
Make sharded shards report zero object stats

Before, when a container had been sharded, its object stats (as
included in the result of get_info()) were taken from the sum of its
shard ranges stats.

With this patchset this is only done if the container is the root
container.

Shards that have sharded have been shrunk, and their effective
object_count and bytes_used should be zero to avoid distorting the
sharded container account stats.

Change-Id: I766de4977e2b766d511545299777f06908a7c0c2

commit_message:
Make update_sharding_info() a broker method

...and get_sharding_info(), so that we can call
them from within a broker instance.

This also makes for slighty better encapsulation of how the
state is persisted (although still imperfect).

Change-Id: I2c907751c526283e1e533c46357e9b949334aa5d

commit_message:
Make sharding state more abstract

...than just the on disk file state.

Also cache the list of on disk files rather than listing dir every
time we want to query the sharding state or db_file.

Also clean up places where we can use get_brokers() rather than
inspecting state and explicitly setting up alternative connections
etc.

Change-Id: I7d591149bde56f8e8648da9e24a26ebc86364a99

messages:
[{'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-02-15 18:31:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-02-15 18:38:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Note: it may prove useful to diff this with master as well as its parent.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-02-16 10:04:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Started looking at this. But because it container replication specific I think I need more brain power then I have at 9pm on a Friday night.

Plan to look, draw and test this on Monday with a fresh mind

From an initial look, looks cleaner, but replication always has subtleties so wanna look closely :)'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-02-16 14:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-02-16 14:15:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

hopefully made probe test listing more predictable with parent patch

with this version I saw OMM:

test_replication_to_sharded_container (test.probe.test_sharder.TestContainerSharding) ... ok
test_replication_to_sharding_container (test.probe.test_sharder.TestContainerSharding) ... ^C
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 2 tests in 166.177s

OK
0 failures / 60 repeats'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:52:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-02-16 17:00:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm still not happy with the cases when replicating from a sharding node to a missing or unsharded node.

With this patch we always merge into an existing db on the remote. So the sharding source h.db rsyncs to create an h.db on the remote, then we merge the content of the source s.db into the remote h.db.

That means that the remote is not in sharding state :/ Similarly if the remote already had a h.db.

BUT if alternatively we rsync the source s.db to the remote, then there is no guarantee that the existing h.db is the correct partner for that s.db.

Either way it seems we need a robust way to detect if the shard db/metadata corresponds to the h.db, and if not then do whatever it takes to recover/restart sharding.

I'm not sure if it is easier to do that given a merged db on the destination or given separate (possibly mismatched) dbs on the destination.

I started playing with the alternative (create separate remote dbs) in a follow on patch to this."}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-02-19 06:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)

Need to go make a start on dinner, so will post up what I have ATM. I hope it makes sense. Just notes and clarifications. Not all the wat through so maybe as I see more things will make more sense.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-02-19 08:17:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-02-19 19:48:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Some of the changes here hopefully make more sense in context of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/536520.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-02-22 17:57:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-02-23 11:13:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-15 18:31:29.000000000', 'message': "Fix and simplify container replication

This patch simplifies the rsync replication paths so they revert to
being closer to master, and fixes some of the rsync scenarios for
sharding or sharded containers.

Details of changes:

1. Before, when the destination was sharded, the first REPLICATE call
would return 404 which would cause rsync to always be used. Now, the
existence of any valid db on the destination will result in a success
response to the first REPLICATE request.

2. Before, in some scenarios, rows from a hash.db might be rsync'd to
a destination *hash.db* even when the destination was sharding or
sharded. That could be problematic given that the shard db would have
previously initialised its row id from a supposedly read-only
hash.db. Now, sync'd rows are always merged into the newest db on the
destination, regardless of the sharding state of the source or
destination. This does mean that the destination shard db could become
bloated if an unsharded source is significantly out of sync, but in
practice this was likely to have happened anyway because large db's
with large rowid's are likely to have been using usync.

3. Before only usync was used when both source or destination was in
sharding state, or when they were in different states. This
restriction is no longer necessary so has been removed to minimise the
differences w.r.t. master branch. The restriction to usync may be a
useful as a means of restricting the rate of sync'ing when a container
is sharding, given that the correct destination for rows is actually a
shard. If so, this feature can be re-introduced. However, in practice
it is likely that usync will be chosen anyway since larger containers
will tend to use usync.

4. If source is in sharding state, each source db is replicated
separately. This means that the decision to use rsync or usync is made
as appropriate for the difference between each db and the
destination. Note that if the destination is also in sharding state,
it's sync status is represented by broker that encapsulates both old
hash.db and shard db, regardless of the source db being sync'd.

As a consequence, the _rsync_db and _rsync_file methods only need to
handle one file at a time, so these methods revert to being very
similar to master. _rsync_db does still append an extra arg
w.r.t. master, which is the source db filename. This is used when
complete_rsync is renaming a new db file on the destination.

5. When doing an rsync_then_merge, merge incoming syncs from the old
destination db to the new destination db. This is significant when
rsync_then_merge is used to sync both db's from a sharding
source. Before, the first source db (hash.db) would rsync_then_merge
and add its sync point to the destination db. When the second source
db was rsync_then_merge'd, the sync point from the previous
rsync_then_merge was lost. This caused the sync of the first db to be
repeated on the next replication cycle. Now the sync point for the
hash.db is retained when the shard.db is rsync_then_merge'd.

6. Adds unit tests for many replication scenarios.

Change-Id: I8cea31896262ee2ac26a440847f6b6cfc836ad37

would return 404 which would cause rsync to always be used. Now, the
existence of any valid db on the destination will result in a success
response to the first REPLICATE request.

2. Before, in some scenarios, rows from a hash.db might be rsync'd to
a destination *hash.db* even when the destination was sharding or
sharded. That could be problematic given that the shard db would have
previously initialised its row id from a supposedly read-only
hash.db. Now, sync'd rows are always merged into the newest db on the
destination, regardless of the sharding state of the source or
destination. This does mean that the destination shard db could become
bloated if an unsharded source is significantly out of sync, but in
practice this was likely to have happened anyway because large db's
with large rowid's are likely to have been using usync.

3. Before only usync was used when both source or destination was in
sharding state, or when they were in different states. This
restriction is no longer necessary so has been removed to minimise the
differences w.r.t. master branch. The restriction to usync may be a
useful as a means of restricting the rate of sync'ing when a container
is sharding, given that the correct destination for rows is actually a
shard. If so, this feature can be re-introduced. However, in practice
it is likely that usync will be chosen anyway since larger containers
will tend to use usync.

4. If source is in sharding state, each source db is replicated
separately. This means that the decision to use rsync or usync is made
as appropriate for the difference between each db and the
destination. However, if an older source db uses usync then the newer
source db will also use usync and will only usync rows if the older db
completed usyncing all of its rows. That avoids any discontinuity in
the order of usynced rows.

Note that if the destination is also in sharding state,
it's sync status is represented by the broker that encapsulates both old
hash.db and shard db, regardless of the source db being sync'd.

As a consequence, the _rsync_db and _rsync_file methods only need to
handle one file at a time, so these methods revert to being very
similar to master. _rsync_db does still append an extra arg
w.r.t. master, which is the source db filename. This is used when
complete_rsync is renaming a new db file on the destination.

5. When doing an rsync_then_merge, merge incoming syncs from the old
destination db to the new destination db. This is significant when
rsync_then_merge is used to sync both db's from a sharding
source. Before, the first source db (hash.db) would rsync_then_merge
and add its sync point to the destination db. When the second source
db was rsync_then_merge'd, the sync point from the previous
rsync_then_merge was lost. This caused the sync of the first db to be
repeated on the next replication cycle. Now the sync point for the
hash.db is retained when the shard.db is rsync_then_merge'd.

6. Adds unit tests for many replication scenarios.

Change-Id: I8cea31896262ee2ac26a440847f6b6cfc836ad37

commit_message:
Fix and simplify container replication

This patch simplifies the rsync replication paths so they revert to
being closer to master, and fixes some of the rsync scenarios for
sharding or sharded containers.

Details of changes:

1. Before, when the destination was sharded, the first REPLICATE call
would return 404 which would cause rsync to always be used. Now, the
existence of any valid db on the destination will result in a success
response to the first REPLICATE request.

2. Before, in some scenarios, rows from a hash.db might be rsync'd to
a destination *hash.db* even when the destination was sharding or
sharded. That could be problematic given that the shard db would have
previously initialised its row id from a supposedly read-only
hash.db. Now, sync'd rows are always merged into the newest db on the
destination, regardless of the sharding state of the source or
destination. This does mean that the destination shard db could become
bloated if an unsharded source is significantly out of sync, but in
practice this was likely to have happened anyway because large db's
with large rowid's are likely to have been using usync.

3. Before only usync was used when both source or destination was in
sharding state, or when they were in different states. This
restriction is no longer necessary so has been removed to minimise the
differences w.r.t. master branch. The restriction to usync may be a
useful as a means of restricting the rate of sync'ing when a container
is sharding, given that the correct destination for rows is actually a
shard. If so, this feature can be re-introduced. However, in practice
it is likely that usync will be chosen anyway since larger containers
will tend to use usync.

4. If source is in sharding state, each source db is replicated
separately. This means that the decision to use rsync or usync is made
as appropriate for the difference between each db and the
destination. However, if an older source db uses usync then the newer
source db will also use usync and will only usync rows if the older db
completed usyncing all of its rows. That avoids any discontinuity in
the order of usynced rows.

Note that if the destination is also in sharding state,
it's sync status is represented by the broker that encapsulates both old
hash.db and shard db, regardless of the source db being sync'd.

As a consequence, the _rsync_db and _rsync_file methods only need to
handle one file at a time, so these methods revert to being very
similar to master. _rsync_db does still append an extra arg
w.r.t. master, which is the source db filename. This is used when
complete_rsync is renaming a new db file on the destination.

5. When doing an rsync_then_merge, merge incoming syncs from the old
destination db to the new destination db. This is significant when
rsync_then_merge is used to sync both db's from a sharding
source. Before, the first source db (hash.db) would rsync_then_merge
and add its sync point to the destination db. When the second source
db was rsync_then_merge'd, the sync point from the previous
rsync_then_merge was lost. This caused the sync of the first db to be
repeated on the next replication cycle. Now the sync point for the
hash.db is retained when the shard.db is rsync_then_merge'd.

6. Adds unit tests for many replication scenarios.

Change-Id: I8cea31896262ee2ac26a440847f6b6cfc836ad37

commit_message:
Handle NodeTLSData resources for controller roles

In ocata (and newton), a custom role in place of the default controller
didn't work, b/c not all of the controller specific resources were
represented in role.role.j2.yaml.

This patch makes it so that at least overcloud SSL configuration is
handled by checking to see if the string "controller" is in the role
name. This fixes the issue of using deployed-server with ssl for ocata.

Change-Id: I7e8487208cc71a0780abc167d06902b9f3d3c983
Closes-Bug: #1751179

[{'created': '2016-07-28 05:28:53.000000000', 'message': 'Base OpenStackClient(OSC) plugin support
This patch enable tackerclient OSC plugin support. This
patch set does the following:
 1. Adds OSC to test-requirement.txt, setup.cfg
 2. Creates the OSC plugin
 3. Builds OSC plugin structure for tacker commands and
unit tests. Such as: VNF, VNFD, VIM, EXT

The OSC plugin system is a command set for following
OpenStack services: Compute, Identity, Image, Object Storage,
Block Storage and Network. Other OpenStack services,
such as Orchestration or Telemetry may create an OpenStackClient
plugin.So Tacker can do the same.

Here is OSC plugin links:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-openstackclient/plugins.html

Here is the blueprint(Tacker OpenStackClient plugin )links:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tacker/+spec/tacker-openstackclient-plugin

Change-Id: I3c785a6e4754c7b9963571d2a703a5d7d160c33f
'}, {'created': '2016-07-28 05:30:51.000000000', 'message': 'Base OpenStackClient(OSC) plugin support

This patch enable tackerclient OSC plugin support. This
patch set does the following:
 1. Adds OSC to test-requirement.txt, setup.cfg
 2. Creates the OSC plugin
 3. Builds OSC plugin structure for tacker commands and
unit tests. Such as: VNF, VNFD, VIM, EXT
 4. Use osc_lib instead of python-openstackclient

The OSC plugin system is a command set for following
OpenStack services: Compute, Identity, Image, Object Storage,
Block Storage and Network. Other OpenStack services,
such as Orchestration or Telemetry may create an OpenStackClient
plugin.So Tacker can do the same.

Here is OSC plugin links:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-openstackclient/plugins.html

Here is the blueprint(Tacker OpenStackClient plugin )links:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tacker/+spec/tacker-openstackclient-plugin

Here is osc-lib  OpenStackClient Plugin Library links:
https://http://docs.openstack.org/developer/osc-lib/

commit_message:
Base OpenStackClient(OSC) plugin support

This patch enable tackerclient OSC plugin support. This
patch set does the following:
 1. Adds OSC to test-requirement.txt, setup.cfg
 2. Creates the OSC plugin
 3. Builds OSC plugin structure for tacker commands and
unit tests. Such as: VNF, VNFD, VIM, EXT
 4. Use osc_lib instead of python-openstackclient
 5. Map tacker commands to openstack commands

The OSC plugin system is a command set for following
OpenStack services: Compute, Identity, Image, Object Storage,
Block Storage and Network. Other OpenStack services,
such as Orchestration or Telemetry may create an OpenStackClient
plugin.So Tacker can do the same.

Here is OSC plugin links:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-openstackclient/plugins.html

Here is the blueprint(Tacker OpenStackClient plugin )links:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tacker/+spec/tacker-openstackclient-plugin

Here is osc-lib  OpenStackClient Plugin Library links:
https://http://docs.openstack.org/developer/osc-lib/

Change-Id: I3c785a6e4754c7b9963571d2a703a5d7d160c33f

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-20 13:54:00.000000000', 'message': 'Ignore Queens release notes in the next release

Some Queens release notes added to master should have been pushed only
to the stable/queens branch, according to Reno documentation [1]. Using
ignore-notes prevents them from appearing in release notes for the next
release (still called "Current").

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/reno/latest/user/usage.html#updating-stable-branch-release-notes

Depends-On: I43e26b315ff285ad75655621cffe8cc4414de37d
Change-Id: I76d42666c9743afc9e727ef90410453b2e541f03
'}]
commit_message:
Ignore Queens release notes in the next release

Some Queens release notes added to master should have been pushed only
to the stable/queens branch, according to Reno documentation [1]. Using
ignore-notes prevents them from appearing in release notes for the next
release (still called "Current").

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/reno/latest/user/usage.html#updating-stable-branch-release-notes

Depends-On: I43e26b315ff285ad75655621cffe8cc4414de37d
Change-Id: I76d42666c9743afc9e727ef90410453b2e541f03

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-06-02 10:56:28.000000000', 'message': "Rename a variable in node_power_action()

There are 2 variables in node_power_action() method.
- new_state:
  indicating power action, which can be reboot or soft power off.
- target_state:
  indicating physical state after the action, which shuold be only
  power on or off.

These variables are a little confusing. This patch rename 'new_state'
to 'power_action' for avoiding the confusion.

Change-Id: Ie030d38abf5c548b85c8a9875bf0da88e2d549a2
"}]
commit_message:
Rename a variable in node_power_action()

There are 2 variables in node_power_action() method.
- new_state:
  indicating power action, which can be reboot or soft power off.
- target_state:
  indicating physical state after the action, which shuold be only
  power on or off.

These variables are a little confusing. This patch rename 'new_state'
to 'power_action' for avoiding the confusion.

Change-Id: Ie030d38abf5c548b85c8a9875bf0da88e2d549a2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-12 12:13:53.000000000', 'message': 'Add a hook to run a bash script at the end of the overcloud prep.

This would be useful for ffu mixed version upgrade testing.  The use
case is test environment only as we want to have a mixed version with
master-uc/netwon-oc.  This is not a normal environment use case and as
such we expect workaround to have this working.

The trouble of maintaining the extra workaround against having a not
too long feedback loop on the ffu upgrade seems worth the trouble.

Change-Id: Ib37b9f58e25b94fe7459b61355d5d15c3f0d36b8
Related-Bug: #1742924

commit_message:
Add a hook to run a bash script at the end of the overcloud prep.

This would be useful for ffu mixed version upgrade testing.  The use
case is test environment only as we want to have a mixed version with
master-uc/netwon-oc.  This is not a normal environment use case and as
such we expect workaround to have this working.

The trouble of maintaining the extra workaround against having a not
too long feedback loop on the ffu upgrade seems worth the trouble.

Change-Id: Ib37b9f58e25b94fe7459b61355d5d15c3f0d36b8
Related-Bug: #1742924

commit_message:
Fix functional tests by using ovs with commit 8b70d82461ea104858ebd7d397ec004f6974240b

Use branch 2.9. The commit 8bf332225d4a73f359c806ad907bcb78ad2a6087
- "ovn-northd: Reduce amount of flow hashing." in ovs master has caused
regressions because of which functional tests are failing. So use the commit
8b70d82461ea104858ebd7d397ec004f6974240b.
We can revert back to master, once the regressions are addressed.

Change-Id: Ic50865033088443769442667385ed303624e7691
Closes-bug: #1750599

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I4d1331f1460c774fa7a6fd88032603668f21f0d4

commit_message:
Use overcloud_templates for deployed server prepare scripts.

This can overcome compatibility issue in mixed version.  This also
check for newton in the overcloud_release.

This is especially important for ffu mixed version ci jobs.

Change-Id: I08d6cfed303fc08fa8a44c267cb3ccc504daa4f6
Related-Bug: #1744036

subject: queens: Enable func tests for xenial/queens
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-23 11:40:43.000000000', 'message': 'queens: Enable func tests for xenial/queens

Fairly major rework in basic deployment test case; queens
no longer needs mongodb, but does require gnocchi, ceph and
memcached in order to deploy and function.

Skip existing test cases related to endpoint and relation
validation for identity-service relation (no longer used at
queens as ceilometer no longer registers API endpoints).

Change-Id: Id31b0dd07b137d68ab0a97c62988790b9376c2e1
'}]
commit_message:
queens: Enable func tests for xenial/queens

Fairly major rework in basic deployment test case; queens
no longer needs mongodb, but does require gnocchi, ceph and
memcached in order to deploy and function.

Skip existing test cases related to endpoint and relation
validation for identity-service relation (no longer used at
queens as ceilometer no longer registers API endpoints).

Change-Id: Id31b0dd07b137d68ab0a97c62988790b9376c2e1

commit_message:
Find the right release file for ffu mixed version upgrade.

By setting ffu_overcloud_upgrade in the featureset this change find
the right previous version for ffu and thus the correct release file.

This also refactor all the upgrade/update related function.

This whole section of the ci code is related to this tech-debt.
Related-Bug: #1749978

Change-Id: I962c2e4ad4eb522839deb904e0c67fb6a5d0ead9

commit_message:
l3: an unit test for set_extra_attr_value

Add an unit test for set_extra_attr_value to check if
exception is raised when it's called out of db transaction.
This patch is follow up for I0e2707222b1f91199cf466c997c0e691679fd3a4

Change-Id: I1c9bdf88ceba8ac07c8501b2f5590bc6adc6c337
Partial-bug: #1745633

[{'created': '2018-02-20 23:59:15.000000000', 'message': "use qos rule type details api def from neutron-lib

The QoS rule type details extension's API definition was rehomed into
neutron-lib with I068fec43604b89dcc6e47c2793f8267c615144b4
This patch consumes it by using the API definition from lib and removing
the rehomed code.

NeutronLibImpact

commit_message:
use qos rule type details api def from neutron-lib

The QoS rule type details extension's API definition was rehomed into
neutron-lib with I068fec43604b89dcc6e47c2793f8267c615144b4
This patch consumes it by using the API definition from lib and removing
the rehomed code.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: I923f7313185a88a1b1b895d5407ec1c3f81d6533

[{'created': '2018-02-22 14:29:23.000000000', 'message': "Fix cache update after initial apt_repository fail

If apt_repository fails to update the apt cache after updating the
configuration, retries don't register there was a change and so no
attempt is made to update the cache by the module on the second attempt.
This failure can result in a failure to install packages.

This change adds an apt module task to update the cache if the
apt_repository task registers a change. This means updating the cache

commit_message:
Fix cache update after initial apt_repository fail

If apt_repository fails to update the apt cache after updating the
configuration, retries don't register there was a change and so no
attempt is made to update the cache by the module on the second attempt.
This failure can result in a failure to install packages.

This change adds an apt module task to update the cache if the
apt_repository task registers a change. This means updating the cache
will get retried on failure and no longer fail silently.

Change-Id: Ia0723407a08a84d5a1a59f4cc3b9006e8587d7b3
Partial-Bug: #1750656

commit_message:
WIP: Check the state of VM to attach or detach a volume

To attach or detach a volume from a VM, if clonable maps are present
they can be reused to create adapters or using dlpar and RMC
capabilities new adapters need to be created. This change adds the
appropriate checks before an attach or detach is done.

Change-Id: Ide1b720cdde03d4dd6419797a7903d90e8cb8b67

[{'created': '2018-02-20 17:17:56.000000000', 'message': 'Persist user-files/* for 'overcloud update' command

Reuse the generic file persistence logic to persist also any files
under "user-files/" path in the plan. These are files that can be

commit_message:
Persist user-files/* for 'overcloud update' command

Reuse the generic file persistence logic to persist also any files
under "user-files/" path in the plan. These are files that can be
potentially referenced from other files in the
plan (e.g. user-environment.yaml) and if they aren't persisted, the
plan could get into inconsistent state (broken references).

Change-Id: I54d10b11e024a481a9ff905a7cce79cb7f562ea0
Closes-Bug: #1749700

commit_message:
Preserve roles_data and network_data

This will make sure that we keep existing roles_data and network_data
during a plan update, unless the user has passed in new files on the
command line.

Partial-Bug: #1749700
Change-Id: Ic059f50f0b2a3a2b20011851cb0b1576192c0d00

messages:
[{'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-01-25 10:06:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2018-01-25 10:15:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-01-25 10:18:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2018-01-25 10:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-01-25 11:04:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2018-01-25 12:56:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-01-25 16:31:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

This assumes that all commands are well behaved. It's possible that a cmd could return 0 in an error case, or print a password in a non-error case. It's probably safer to continue sanitizing output in all cases. Could maybe add a flag that the caller can pass in to say that isn't necessary, in case they know the command _is_ well behaved."}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-02 14:59:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-05 13:36:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-05 13:46:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-05 13:47:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-05 13:49:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Published edit on patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-05 13:50:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Published edit on patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-05 14:24:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-06 18:50:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10: Patch Set 9 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-06 19:01:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Published edit on patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-02-12 16:22:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

minor cleanups and then I'll +1"}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-12 18:31:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Published edit on patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-02-12 18:49:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-02-19 22:38:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

In addition to the clarifying change I describe inline, we need tests for the new cases (combinations for sanitize_stdout true/false and where the command succeeds/fails). Some of those cases may be covered by existing tests, but since there is a new argument to the function not all of them are.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-21 19:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13: Patch Set 12 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-21 19:42:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Published edit on patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 24005, 'date': '2018-02-21 19:44:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-25 10:06:02.000000000', 'message': 'Mask passwords only when command execution fails

At many places, processutils.ssh_execute() is being invoked to run
a command over ssh and output returned is parsed to get appropriate
information. In this flow, unsanitized output is being expected
where processutils.ssh_execute() was invoked but found that
output like volume details(containing "password" string in its name)
is being masked away with strutils.mask_password(stdout) eventhough
no error occured during command execution.

This is regression issue from patch[0]. In this fix, stdout and stderr
in processutils.ssh_execute() will be masked only when
ProcessExecutionError exception is thrown i.e. command execution failed
due to some reasons.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.concurrency/commit/
ae9e05bfc3d7ec867bd6ec78c301f11c2bdd0d5f

Change-Id: I2ce344330905eef437ef3f89a2a01169a30df8ab
Closes-Bug: #1482382
'}, {'created': '2018-01-25 10:18:17.000000000', 'message': 'Mask passwords only when command execution fails

At many places, processutils.ssh_execute() is being invoked to run
a command over ssh and output returned is parsed to get appropriate
information. In this flow, unsanitized output is being expected
where processutils.ssh_execute() was invoked but found that
output like volume details(containing "password" string in its name)
is being masked away with strutils.mask_password(stdout) even though
no error occured during command execution.

This is regression issue from patch[0]. In this fix, stdout and stderr
in processutils.ssh_execute() will be masked only when
ProcessExecutionError exception is thrown i.e. command execution failed
due to some reasons.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.concurrency/commit/
ae9e05bfc3d7ec867bd6ec78c301f11c2bdd0d5f

Change-Id: I2ce344330905eef437ef3f89a2a01169a30df8ab
Closes-Bug: #1482382
'}, {'created': '2018-01-25 11:04:46.000000000', 'message': 'Mask passwords only when command execution fails

At many places, processutils.ssh_execute() is being invoked to run
a command over ssh and output returned is parsed to get appropriate
information. In this flow, unsanitized output is being expected
where processutils.ssh_execute() was invoked but found that
output like volume details(containing "password" string in its name)
is being masked away with strutils.mask_password(stdout) even though
no error occured during command execution.

This is regression issue from patch[0]. In this fix, stdout and stderr
in processutils.ssh_execute() will be masked only when

commit_message:
Mask passwords only when command execution fails

At many places, processutils.ssh_execute() is being invoked to run
a command over ssh and output returned is parsed to get appropriate
information. In this flow, unsanitized output is being expected
where processutils.ssh_execute() was invoked but found that
output like volume details(containing "password" string in its name)
is being masked away with strutils.mask_password(stdout) even though
no error occured during command execution.

This is regression issue from patch[0]. In this fix, stdout and stderr
in processutils.ssh_execute() will be masked only when
ProcessExecutionError exception is thrown i.e. command execution failed
due to some reasons.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.concurrency/commit/
ae9e05bfc3d7ec867bd6ec78c301f11c2bdd0d5f

Change-Id: I2ce344330905eef437ef3f89a2a01169a30df8ab
Closes-Bug: #1482382

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-19 12:34:23.000000000', 'message': '[Fullstack] Respawn dhclient process in case of error

When dhclient process is started as async process by fake machine resource,
it might happen that "None" will be returned as first line of output
from this process.
Than cause killing async process due to error and IP address is then
not configured and fullstack test fails because of that.

This patch adds "respawn_timeout" value set to 5 seconds for dhclient
async process. When dhclient process is restarted it should works fine
and IP address should be then configured properly.

Change-Id: Ie056578abbe6e18c8415c6e61d755f2248a70541
Closes-Bug: #1728948

commit_message:
[Fullstack] Respawn dhclient process in case of error

When dhclient process is started as async process by fake machine resource,
it might happen that "None" will be returned as first line of output
from this process. This is treated as an error and dhclient is halted
immediately.
Because of that fake machine don't have configured IP address and
test fails.

This patch adds "respawn_timeout" value set to 5 seconds for dhclient
async process. When dhclient process is restarted it should works fine
and IP address should be then configured properly.

Change-Id: Ie056578abbe6e18c8415c6e61d755f2248a70541
Closes-Bug: #1728948

commit_message:
Use the generic preservation method for plan-environment.yaml

This reuses the previously introduced generic file preservation method
in a deployment plan to keep plan-environment.yaml too.

We can also get rid of the separate password keeping, as they are part
of the plan-environment.yaml.

Partial-Bug: #1749700
Change-Id: Ib64296daaa81ff4fb19f1c199ecd6507ab2fb71c

commit_message:
[upstream] Add a note about notifying PTL to cont workflow

I had a comment after my presentation today that it would be
good to mention the fact that notifying the PTL that you
are interested in participating is helpful.  This is a good thing
to add to building your persona.

This patch adds that.

Change-Id: Icc82a9cf1568b6bb9c96d491f3591b3d34b4a406

commit_message:
Role apache-logs-conf: fix redhat matching

Ansible complains:

  The task includes an option with an undefined variable. The error
  was: 'dict object' has no attribute 'RedHat'

which is just a mismatch on the "Redhat" string

Change-Id: I447038256561740c224c68388fa5b6a068cc8fed

[{'created': '2017-11-11 10:10:15.000000000', 'message': "Fix race condition on ovn_client on startup

On startup, when we initialize the IDL we start receiving notifications
right away and processing them. There's a possibility that even though
the IDLs are initialized, post_fork_initialize has not yet created the
ovn_client object resulting in an exception (and also possible missing
DB updates) if attempted to be used.

This patch fixes this by converting ovn_client object in mech driver
into a property which initializes it if doesn't exist yet.

commit_message:
Fix race condition on ovn_client on startup

On startup, when we initialize the IDL we start receiving notifications
right away and processing them. There's a possibility that even though
the IDLs are initialized, post_fork_initialize has not yet created the
ovn_client object resulting in an exception (and also possible missing
DB updates) if attempted to be used.

This patch fixes this by converting ovn_client object in mech driver
into a property which initializes it if doesn't exist yet.

Change-Id: I3965ae61fb5ba7dda07bb797a09383a6c35f589e
Closes-Bug: #1731288
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2017-12-11 17:57:18.000000000', 'message': "Initialize privsep in networking-ovn-metadata-agent

We were not initializing privsep in the metadata agent so we weren't
using any root helper to call it. In devstack this is not a problem
since 'stack' user can execute anything but in TripleO deployments
it won't work since user 'neutron' is only allowed to execute commands
through rootwrap/rootwrap-daemon. This patch initializes privsep which
whatever root_helper is configured.

Change-Id: I8b1552f5adfef4f3fb114445b463a4c77b25ac9c
Closes-Bug: #1737587
"}]
commit_message:
Initialize privsep in networking-ovn-metadata-agent

We were not initializing privsep in the metadata agent so we weren't
using any root helper to call it. In devstack this is not a problem
since 'stack' user can execute anything but in TripleO deployments
it won't work since user 'neutron' is only allowed to execute commands
through rootwrap/rootwrap-daemon. This patch initializes privsep which
whatever root_helper is configured.

Change-Id: I8b1552f5adfef4f3fb114445b463a4c77b25ac9c
Closes-Bug: #1737587

commit_message:
kube.sh: don't download kubectl again when it exists

kubectl is a single executable binary with the size of 67M. With this
commit the binary won't be downloaded when it already exists. This helps
save some time and network bandwidth when testing.

Change-Id: I0f4de5d0eb6e8f7a73d10f8636432519ae961e64

commit_message:
use router service type api def from neutron-lib

The router service type extension's API definition was rehomed into
neutron-lib with If9f7dfd246dded780761bcad83537985d0a22b52
This patch consumes it by removing the rehomed code and using the
API definition with the APIExtensionDescriptor parent class.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: I6a87dc5ce3e3891001a3f571b4676f5befbaabbb

commit_message:
Add probe test to delete then revive a sharded container

Check that a sharded container can be deleted when all shards are
empty but becomes undeleted if an async update subsequently arrives
at a shard.

Also, change condition for a container to be considered as 'sharding
enabled', such that a deleted root container which has shard ranges
will still be considered as 'sharding enabled'.

Change-Id: I02d3a242e84c5f4eaabd7a94c461a10b86a1905e

[{'created': '2018-02-22 16:44:20.000000000', 'message': 'Clarify `resources` query param for /r_p and /a_c

It was pointed out [1] that the semantic difference between how the
`resources` query parameter is handled by GET /resource_providers versus
GET /allocation_candidates is not clear based on the API reference
descriptions, which are identical.  This change set clarifies the
wording for both, making it clear that a) allocations are taking into
account; and b) GET /allocation_candidates is working with groups of
providers that must *collectively* satisfy the resource specification.

Change-Id: Ia2a4f8f80ec68dd9c95e084c292a2fe2d6ec1b2d

GET /allocation_candidates is not clear based on the API reference
descriptions, which are identical.  This change set clarifies the
wording for both, making it clear that a) allocations are taking into
account; and b) GET /allocation_candidates is working with groups of
providers that must *collectively* satisfy the resource specification.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/547056/2/specs/rocky/approved/traits-on-list-resource-providers.rst@33
Change-Id: Ia2a4f8f80ec68dd9c95e084c292a2fe2d6ec1b2d
'}]
commit_message:
Clarify `resources` query param for /r_p and /a_c

It was pointed out [1] that the semantic difference between how the
`resources` query parameter is handled by GET /resource_providers versus
GET /allocation_candidates is not clear based on the API reference
descriptions, which are identical.  This change set clarifies the
wording for both, making it clear that a) allocations are taking into
account; and b) GET /allocation_candidates is working with groups of
providers that must *collectively* satisfy the resource specification.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/547056/2/specs/rocky/approved/traits-on-list-resource-providers.rst@33
Change-Id: Ia2a4f8f80ec68dd9c95e084c292a2fe2d6ec1b2d

commit_message:
Bump ovsb_connection_timeout from 5 to 15 s in functional tests

Due to recent bump of ovsdbapp from 0.9.0 to 0.9.1, we see
functional tests failing in the gate for both master and
stable/queens branch due to timeouts in the transactions to
OVSDB. This patch bumps the default timeout to 15 seconds for
functional tests.

Related-Bug: #1750599

Change-Id: I3f0157a9cf67bdb547bcab5dac0d696528564c52
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Allow to pass search filter in the query metric value

Follow patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/370629/
You can use the filter to query metric values on server side.
Now only support simple binary operators.

Change-Id: I34ce5b6258a122e9ab5880bf3694b295ed1a9527

commit_message:
Add check for directory names

directory names should be pypi-names. So add a check
that a pypi release is available for all directories.

Depends-On: Icedd41ce74b905fef2c46b493b094aa98b697f98
Change-Id: I112d54cee68be3411b4c49d0b1cded42b88c9a0a

commit_message:
Fix warning for user_id and project_id

saw this in the log:
nova/context.py:108: DeprecationWarning: Using the 'user' argument is deprecated in version '2.18' and will be removed in version '3.0', please use the 'user_id' argument instead
DeprecationWarning: Using the 'tenant' argument is deprecated in version '2.18' and will be removed in version '3.0', please use the 'project_id' argument instead

Change-Id: Ia9973f1c007328371ba5281c16a6e0a030e1bc2d

commit_message:
SUSE review policy fixes: RPM group / dot at summary

SUSE still requires a RPM group to be set unfortunately.
Add one.

Change-Id: Ib4dfcea07a0fa2e8a3de3e0e891350242092f0ef

You're right that it was initially wrong, but how you've changed it doesn't really get the necessary nuance."}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2018-02-15 10:00:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2018-02-15 10:02:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Thanks for the comment.

Here's a second try without low level terms like 'capacity'.

I also started to diverge the two pieces of text because of their different contexts. I feel we can safely refer to placement (or allocation) in the context of list-allocation-candidates. But we shouldn't in the context of list-resource-providers because nothing is allocated there, not even tentatively.

They may also diverge further because of nesting. AFAIU candidates will offer subtrees, but resource provider listing must produce individual resource providers."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-02-15 10:07:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

commit_message:
Clarify 'capacity' in placement api-ref

According to the discussion in the bug report 'capacity' in the ref
means the currently available capacity. We clear that up here but
without referring to low level terminology.

Change-Id: Idd4dad44eb9d1155e8040849eb73868bc608c67d
Closes-Bug: #1749410
