subject: Make HA deployments the default
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 4328, 'name': 'Steven Hardy', 'email': 'shardy@redhat.com', 'username': 'shardy'}, {'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 7144, 'name': 'James Slagle', 'email': 'jslagle@redhat.com', 'username': 'slagle'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-20 15:49:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-20 15:51:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-02-20 15:53:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

would it be cleaner to just use plan-environment.yaml?'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-20 15:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I fully support this!'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2018-02-20 16:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

plan-environment.yaml is pretty opaque to the user and not really documented on how to use it at this point.

i like this patch. sane defaults make sense. why would we maintain overcloud-resource-registry.j2.yaml with anything other than the defaults we expect to be used?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-02-20 16:28:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2018-02-20 17:01:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

we should add an environment for the old deprecated way, e.g., puppet-nonha.yaml which allows for restoring the previous mappings for overcloud-resource-registry-puppet'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-20 18:17:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I deliberately didn't provide a way to enable the baremetal old-way, as I thought we wanted to deprecate and eventually remove baremetal support?

There is the environments/nonha-arch.yaml file which can reinstate the nonha mode for folks that need it, and I set the same configuration for the undercloud which is always nonha atm."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-02-20 18:51:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-20 20:47:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

(1 comment)

WIP pending further feedback from Dan - I'm still a bit unclear why he -2'd this and we've not had a chance to chat about it yet"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-20 20:56:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-02-20 21:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-21 08:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-02-21 12:54:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The use case I'm thinking about here is potentially a 'packstack' type installer replacement which would support both containers and baremetal. The 'undercloud deploy' command actually already supports baremetal quite nicely. It was how the feature was initially developed:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/tripleo-composable-undercloud

While I agree that our target default for the 'undercloud' is containerization I really liked layering in the containers support via environment files rather than hard coding the resource registry like we are doing here. It just seems more flexible to me that way.

Also, my nit here is the patch says it is changing the HA defaults but perhaps what we really need to address is are containers now our default. Even if we switch defaults I had thought we would keep support for non-HA baremetal deployments around for the time being. Some still prefer it I think.

----

Anyways consider this a soft -2 for the time being. Just wanted to slow this down for a few days while we gathered thoughts on it."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-02-21 12:56:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

In addition to the 'packstack' case above I think the baremetal architecture is potentially useful in single node (undercloud) form as a potential gating tool as well on some platforms where containers may or may not be an option."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-21 17:37:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> but perhaps what we really need to address is are containers now our default.

Thanks for the feedback Dan, perhaps you can review the other patch in this series which does exactly this?

I'm open to a different approach, but I was under the impression we were trying to reduce our test-matrix and standardize on containers.

If we want to keep the baremetal support around for another cycle that's fine, but wrt the "packstack" all-in-one use-case, again I had assumed we'd just support it via containers vs trying to maintain two approaches indefinitely.

Maybe this warrants further discussion at the PTG next week?'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-21 17:42:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

One final note - maintaining both architectures isn't free, not only due to CI, but because we end up with so many nested stacks.

Dan - Next time you run an undercloud deploy time how long the ServiceChain takes to create, if we flatten the templates without creating 3 (or in some cases even more) nested stacks *per service* we can make that much faster I expect.

That said there are probably other ways we could optimize for that, but I favor streamlining the templates if possible."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 08:40:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

> maintaining both architectures isn't free, not only due to CI, but because we end up with so many nested stacks

this ^^ . The benefits of defaulting to HA and containers for overcloud resource registries in t-h-t are HUGE. Lets default like that for Queens, then for undercloud as well (may be not for HA UC tho) for Rocky. This really would reduce a lot the RDO/upstream CI matrixes and save HW resources, and drastically reduce the deployment times and code maintenance burden (for the master branch). Do we really want to keep and maintain (in the master branch) those deprecated non-HA and non-containerized (aka baremetal) deployed services' templates and nested stacks debug complexity for the next 5 years of the downstream LTS release?"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-23 09:46:06.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Dan hasn't responded to my requests to discuss this, so I'll abandon and we can discuss this at the PTG"}]

commit_message:
Make HA deployments the default

This aligns the defaults with what we know is most well tested for
overcloud deployments (particularly for production), but we retain
the old nonha configuration for environments/undercloud.yaml
and if operators specify environments/nonha-arch.yaml.

Change-Id: I0c4869be90cd65051b4509625182fc192fd9b43e

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-20 16:08:29.000000000', 'message': 'Bump ovsb_connection_timeout from 5 to 15 s in functional tests

Due to recent bump of ovsdbapp from 0.9.0 to 0.9.1, we see
functional tests failing in the gate for both master and
stable/queens branch due to timeouts in the transactions to
OVSDB. This patch bumps the default timeout to 15 seconds for
functional tests.

Related-Bug: #1750599

Change-Id: I3f0157a9cf67bdb547bcab5dac0d696528564c52
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
